choices.text: Mostly occurs as a result of twisting force

Almost always associated with meniscal injury

questions.text: True about anterior cruciate ligament is/are:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D)

 

 

ACL

 

  • It is intracapsular, extrasynovial.
  • It is major stabilizer of knee.
  • Its mechanism is to stabilize internal rotation and extension of tibia on femur.
  • Its function is multiple in that it limits forward gliding of tibia on femur and limits hyperextension.
  • It makes a significant contribution to lateral stability and limits anterolateral rotation of tibia on femur.
  • It is injured by occurrence of excessive movements which it limits.
  • Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is most important for walking downhill.
  • Tests for Anterior Cruciate Ligament:
    • Lachman’s test (most sensitive done at 20° knee flexion)
    • Anterior drawer test (done at 90° of knee flexion)
    • Pivot shift test flexion rotation drawer test (2nd best)
    • Test for ACL in decreasing order of sensitivity and specificity:
      • Lachman’s test > flexion rotation drawer test > anterior drawer test > pivot shift phenomenon tested by lateral pivot shift test of Macintosh or jerk test of Hughston and loose.

 

 

Anterior drawer test

 

 

Lachman’s test

 

  • Lelli test (New test for ACL)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anterior cruciate ligament injury mostly occurs as a result of twisting force to the knee.
  • It may occur secondary to tibial fracture and is almost always associated with meniscal injury.

questions.text: Disc prolapse is common at all site except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T3-T4

 

Option D)

 

DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine.
  • In more than 95% of cases, lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases).
  • The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6).
  • Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence, more prone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. L4-L5. This is the commonest site for lumbar disc prolapse.

 

Option B. L5-S1. This is the second commonest site after L4-L5.

 

Option C. C6-C7. Disc prolapse in this region is quite uncommon.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Disc prolapse is not frequently seen in the T3-T4 region. They may be underdiagnosed because they are small and their signs and symptoms may mimic a cervical problem involving the shoulders and even the arms.

questions.text: Identify the deformity.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mallet Finger

 

Option D)

 

MALLET FINGER/BASEBALL FINGER

 

  • It is avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx.
  • Presentation and Type:
    • The terminal phalanx is held flexed and patient cannot straighten it, but passive movement is normal.
    • The proximal interphalangeal joint may become hyperextended due to unbalanced extensor mechanism (Swan neck).

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Swan neck deformity. Swan neck deformity is characterized by proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint flexion. There is also reciprocal flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. This is a result of an imbalance of the extensor mechanism of the digit.

 

 

Option B. Boutonniere deformity. Boutonniere deformity is described as finger flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) and hyperextension at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). This is usually a result of an acute trauma or rupture of the PIP central slip.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows a mallet finger involving flexion of the terminal phalanx.

choices.text: Road traffic accident

questions.text: Most common cause of amputation in India is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Road traffic accident

 

Option C)

AMPUTATION

 

Indications of Amputation:

 

  • Absolute:
    • Irreparable loss of blood supply of a diseased or injured limb
    • Fulminant infection (e.g. gas gangrene)
    • Microvascular ischemia (Burgers gangrene)
    • Diabetic gangrene
  • Relative:
    • Infections
    • Burn
    • Frostbite
    • Trauma
    • Tumors
    • Nerve injuries – rare
    • Congenital anomalies – rare
    • Chronic osteomyelitis – rare

 

Note: Most common cause of amputation is peripheral vascular disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diabetes gangrene. Diabetes gangrene is the common cause of amputation in elderly patients.

 

Option B. Gas gangrene. Amputation due to gas gangrene is rarely seen in India.

 

Option D. Tumors. Among the tumors, osteosarcoma is the common cause of amputation but it can be prevented by use of other limb preserving measures. 

 

Educational objective:
 

  • Trauma like road traffic accidents are the most common causes of amputation among the young population in India.

questions.text: Patient comes with crush injury to upper limb, doctor is concerned about gangrene and sepsis. What can help decide between amputation and limb salvage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MESS

 

Option A)

 

MANGLED EXTREMITY SEVERITY SCORE (MESS)

 

  • Mangled extremity severity score (MESS) can be used as predictor of eventual amputation versus limb salvage in crushing injuries.
  • Higher the score, lower the chances of salvage, i.e. higher score has higher chances of amputation.
  • However, recent studies have shown it to be inaccurate in predicting the functional outcome for mangled limb patient.
  • “SIVA” – the destroyer will decide survival.

 

 

 

  • MESS Score:
    • Total Score is 11
    • Six or less is consistent with a salvageable limb.
    • Seven or greater score, amputation is generally the eventual result.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. GCS score. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to objectively describe the extent of impaired consciousness in all acute medical and trauma patients. The scale assesses patients according to three aspects of responsiveness: eye-opening, motor, and verbal responses. Reporting each of these separately provides a clear, communicable picture of a patient’s state. The score expression is the sum of the scores as well as the individual elements. For example, a score of 10 might be expressed as GCS10 = E3V4M3. The Glasgow Coma Scale divides into three parameters: best eye response (E), best verbal response (V) and best motor response (M). The levels of response are ‘scored’ from 1, for no response, up to normal values of 4 (Eye-opening response), 5 (Verbal response) and 6 (Motor response). The total Score has values between 3 and 15; 3 being the worst and 15 being the highest. 

 

 

Option C. Gustilo-Anderson classification. The purpose of the Gustilo-Anderson classification is to provide a prognostic framework that guides treatment for open (or compound) fractures, with higher grade injuries associated with higher risk of complications.

 

 

Option D. ASIA guidelines. The American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) Impairment Scale is a standardized neurological examination used by the rehabilitation team to assess the sensory and motor levels affected by the spinal cord injury. The scale has five classification levels, ranging from complete loss of neural function in the affected area to completely normal. The results to set functional goals based on the neurological level of injury.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To decide between amputation and limb salvage, MESS scoring system is used. Higher the score, higher the chances of amputation.

questions.text: Jaipur foot was invented by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dr. P.K. Sethi

 

Option A)

 

 

Jaipur foot by Dr. PK Sethi
 

  • The Jaipur foot is a rubber-based prosthetic leg for below-knee amputations.
  • Although inferior in many ways to the composite carbon fibre variants, its variable applicability and cost efficiency make it an acceptable choice for prosthesis.
  • It was designed and developed by Ram Chandra Sharma and orthopedic surgeon Dr. P.K. Sethi in 1968.
  • The Jaipur foot consists of a rubber core, wooden block and vulcanised rubber coating.
  • It is a soft multi-axial artificial foot that provides enough dorsiflexion to permit an amputee to squat.
  • Use of the Jaipur foot is limited to prosthetic users at the level of household and limited community ambulation, since it is unsuitable for high level activities and sports or if the user transverse uneven terrain.
  • Design:
    • The Jaipur foot is composed of a wooden ankle and a rubber heel and forefoot section, all surrounded by a thin outer layer of tire cord, a rubber composite.
    • It is a modification of the Solid Ankle Cushioned Heel (SACH) foot, with the wooden ankle of the SACH foot replaced with a more flexible block of rubber, which allows the user to squat or sit cross-legged.
    • The wooden shank of the SACH foot is replaced with an aluminum shank. 
    • Jaipur foot is made of high-density polyethylene, which is lighter and increases the durability and the convenience of use. However, the Jaipur foot is still heavier than standard prosthetics.
    • The Jaipur foot has some advantages relative to SACH foot, especially in the range of movements it offers. It is possible to move the ankle and foot due to the shorter keel and rubber ankle. The materials used at the foot-end are waterproof and somewhat mimic a real foot. These features help amputees using the foot more easily in a semi-urban or rural setup.
    • It has a typical lifespan of around 2-5 years.
       
  • Difference between SACH foot and Jaipur foot are:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Jaipur foot was invented by Dr. PK Sethi, an orthopedic surgeon in 1968.

choices.text: Gate theory of pain control
Decreases substance P
Local heat at the site

questions.text: What is the principle of TENS which is used for alleviating pain around joints and nerve pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gate theory of pain control
 

Option A)

 

  • TENS and interferential therapy works on the principle of inhibiting pain gate pathway, hence are better for control of neurogenic pain.
  • It is also used to control the pain related to amputation neuroma.
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • The stimulation delivered by the TENS excite (stimulate) the sensory nerves, and activate specific natural pain relief mechanisms.
    • There are two primary pain relief mechanisms which can be activated: the Pain Gate Mechanism and the Endogenous Opioid System.
    • Pain relief by means of the pain gate mechanism involves activation of the Aβ sensory fibers which reduces the transmission of the noxious stimulus from the ‘c’ fibers, through the spinal cord and hence, on to the higher centers.
    • The Aβ fibers are stimulated at a relatively high frequency (90-130 Hz).
    • An alternative approach is to stimulate the Aδ fibers which respond to a much low frequency (2-5 Hz), which will activate the opioid mechanisms, and provide pain relief by causing the release of an endogenous opiate (encephalin) in the spinal cord which will reduce the activation of the noxious sensory pathways.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The TENS modality alleviates the neurogenic pain by the principle of pain gate mechanism.

questions.text: In Amputation neuroma, treatment modality used is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interferential therapy

 

Option D)

 

  • If TENS is mentioned, then that is a better answer.

 

AMPUTATION NEUROMA

 

  • The nerve ending at the stump forms a neuroma that is extremely painful.
     
  • A painful neuroma occurs when the nerve end is subjected to pressure or repeated irritation.
  • A painful neuroma usually can be prevented by gentle traction on the nerve followed by sharp proximal division, allowing the nerve end to retract deep into the soft tissue.
     
  • A painful neuroma usually is easily palpable and often has a positive tinel sign.
     
  • Treatment initially consists of socket modification.
     
  • If this fails to relieve symptoms, simple neuroma excision or a more proximal neurectomy may be required and the pain is controlled through Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) > Interferential therapy > Ultrasound.
     
  • TENS and interferential therapy works on the principle of inhibiting pain gate pathway hence are better for control of neurogenic pain.
     
  • Surgical treatment is considered better than other methods.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ultrasound. The primary options for treatment of painful amputation neuromas include medication and invasive surgery. For certain patients, ultrasound could provide a non-invasive alternative to surgery with less risk of complications. It can reach the desired target without damaging surrounding tissue and is repeatable, if necessary.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • TENS is the modality of choice to control the pain of amputation neuroma after failure of other conservative methods.
  • The effectiveness of other pain control modalities that can be used in such cases is: TENS > IFT > Ultrasonic

questions.text: About SACH Foot, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Squatting is easy

 

Option C)

 

  • SACH foot does not allow ankle movements (required for squatting), subtalar movements (inversion and eversion movements for walking on uneven grounds).
  • Hence, more suitable for western lifestyle and in Jaipur foot, these movements are permitted. Hence, more suitable for Indian scenario.
  • Also, Jaipur foot is appropriate for walking barefoot and with SACH foot, barefoot walking is not possible.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • SACH foot is a solid ankle cushion, heel prosthesis.
  • With this prosthesis, squatting is not possible as it restricts movements in all directions.
  • It does not look like a normal foot and requires a closed shoe for protection, thus barefoot walking is not possible with the SACH foot.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffers from road traffic accident where a car run-over his right leg. On examination, his vitals are stable and general physical examination is okay. His right leg is crushed with exposed muscles and bones. The debate about limbs survival can be resolved to an extent by MESS score. It includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nerve injury

 

Option D)

 

MESS SCORE

 

  • Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) score comprises of ELISA:
    • Energy: Velocity of Trauma
    • Limb ischemia: Distal Circulation
    • Shock: Blood Pressure
    • Age of Patient
       

 

 

  • MESS score equal to or more than 7 – Amputation is indicated.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The MESS score used as a predictor for limb salvage after crush injuries comprises of monitoring of BP, Distal circulation and know about the history of trauma including the Velocity of trauma.

 

 

  • The Nerve injury is not included in it.

questions.text: Myodesis is employed in amputations for all of the following indications except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ischemia

 

Option D)

 

  • Muscles usually are divided at least 5 cm distal to the intended bone resection.
  • They may be stabilized by Myofascial flaps (muscle is attached to fascia), Myodesis (suturing muscle or tendon to bone) or by myoplasty (suturing muscle to periosteum or to fascia of opposing musculature).
  • If possible, myodesis should be performed to provide a stronger insertion, help maximize strength, and minimize atrophy.
  • Myodesed muscles continue to counterbalance their antagonists, preventing contractures and maximizing residual limb function.
  • Myodesis may be contraindicated, however, in severe ischemia because of the increased risk of wound breakdown.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Myodesis or the technique of suturing the muscle or tendon or bone to stabilize the muscles during bone resection in amputation is indicated in cases of a trauma or a tumor.
  • It can also be done in children.
  • It is contraindicated in case of a severe ischemia because of the increased risk of wound breakdown.

questions.text: In closed method of amputation, which structure is kept shorter than the level of amputation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nerves

 

Option C)

 

“Nerves are divided proximal to the bone.”

 

CLOSED AMPUTATION

 

  • Nerves are retracted and cut, so that they are not superficial on stump and cause pain.
  • Bone is kept shorter than soft tissue in flap method of amputation to facilitate closure of amputation stump.
  • Muscles usually are divided at least 5 cm distal to the intended bone resection. They may be stabilized by Myofascial flaps (muscle is attached to fascia), Myodesis (suturing muscle or tendon to bone) or by myoplasty (suturing muscle to periosteum or to fascia of opposing musculature).
  • If possible, myodesis should be performed to provide a stronger insertion, help maximize strength, and minimize atrophy.
  • Myodesed muscles continue to counterbalance their antagonists, preventing contractures and maximizing residual limb function.
  • Myodesis may be contraindicated, however, in severe ischemia because of the increased risk of wound breakdown.
  • The skin and soft tissue are closed primarily.
  • Thus, nerves are cut most proximal then bone and then muscles.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Nerves are kept shorter than the level of amputation because if they are kept superficial, they cause pain.

questions.text: In reconstruction of limb, what is done first?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bone fixation

 

Option A)

 

  • Remember, 1st preserved is skin!

 

REIMPLANTATION OF AMPUTATED DIGIT (GREENS) ORDER OF REPAIR OF STRUCTURES
 

  1. Locate and tag vessels and nerves
  2. Debride
  3. Shorten and fix bone
  4. Repair extensor tendon
  5. Repair flexor tendon
  6. Repair arteries
  7. Repair nerves
  8. Repair veins
  9. Skin coverage

 

 

Note: Skin is preserved the first as there has to be an adequate soft tissue coverage over deeper structures and sensation of palmar skin cannot be reproduced by any skin graft.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Arteries, veins and nerves are reconstructed towards the end in the limb reconstruction in the order of arteries > nerves > veins.
  • After debridement, the bone is shortened and fixed first.

choices.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test
It is the main restraint to internal rotation

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the main restraint to internal rotation

 

Option C)

 

PCL

 

  • Stouter ligamentous structure.
  • It is intracapsular, extrasynovial.
  • It limits backward glide of tibia on femur (posterior translation) and checks hyperextension only after the ACL is ruptured.
  • PCL restricts External rotation as well.
  • Classically injured by high velocity trauma with posterior dislocation of tibia on a flexed knee as in a dash board impact in a motor car (Remember Dash Board Injury is posterior dislocation of hip also).
  • Posterior cruciate ligament is active in all knee movements.
  • Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is most important for walking uphill.
  • Tests for Posterior Cruciate Ligament:
    • Posterior tibial sag
    • Posterior drawer test
    • Reverse pivot shift test
    • Quadriceps active test
  • Treatment is Arthroscopic reconstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCL is the main restraint in posterior drawer test.
  • It is an extrasynovial structure.
  • It is the main restraint to posterior translation of the knee i.e., backward gliding of the tibia on femur.
  • It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch.

questions.text: Muscle with intra-articular tendon:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popliteus

 

Option A)

 

  • The popliteal muscle originates from the posteromedial aspect of the proximal tibia and gives rise to its tendon, which courses intra-articularly through the popliteal hiatus of the coronary ligament to insert on the popliteal saddle on the lateral femoral condyle.
  • The Posterolateral Corner (PLC) is a complex that includes the lateral collateral ligament (LCL), popliteus tendon, fabellofibular ligament, arcuate ligament, popliteofibular ligament, and the short lateral ligament.

questions.text: Snapping knee syndrome is due to involvement of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pes Anserinus

 

Option A)

 

SNAPPING KNEE SYNDROME

 

  • Snapping of tendons at the posteromedial corner of the knee when knee goes into extension from flexion.
  • Tendons of pes anserinus (Semitendinosus and Gracilis) are involved.
  • It is the main extraarticular cause of snapping at the medial knee.
  • There is impingement of the semitendinosus and gracilis tendons against the tibial condyle at 15° extension when returning from a flexed position of the knee.
  • Clinically, snaps are palpated against the medial condyle of the proximal tibia and the patient experiences tenderness when the pes anserinus is palpated.
  • This condition has been reported in volleyball players and women who wear high-heeled shoes, both of these situations are associated with a degree of knee recurvatum.
  • Treatment usually consists of tenotomy with or without partial resection of the gracilis and semitendinosus tendons.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Snapping knee syndrome is caused by the inflammation of the tendons of the pes anserine i.e., the semitendinosus and the gracilis, when the knee goes into extension from a flexed position.

questions.text: Lachman’s test is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ACL injury

 

Option A)

 

LACHMAN’S TEST

 

  • Lachman’s test is the most sensitive test for anterior cruciate ligament tears.
  • It is done with the knee flexed at 20°.
  • The test relies on proper positioning and technique and is regarded as the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing acute ACL injuries. 
  • It is considered a variant of the anterior drawer test.
  • So, it can be done in acute as well as chronic injuries (because in acute cases with hemarthrosis, more flexion is usually not possible so, performing anterior drawer test is difficult as it is performed in 90° knee flexion).
     
  • Technique:
    • The patient is positioned supine with their injured knee flexed to 20 to 30 degrees while also slightly externally rotating the injured leg to relax the iliotibial band.  
    • The examiner then uses one hand to stabilize the distal femur and the other hand to grasp the proximal tibia.
    • Next, an anterior force is applied to the proximal tibia in an attempt to sublux the tibia forward while keeping the femur stabilized.
    • The test is considered positive if there is excessive anterior translation of the proximal tibia greater than the uninjured side and also a lack of a firm endpoint.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. PCL Injury. Special tests for PCL injury are posterior tibial sag test, posterior drawer test, reverse pivot shift test, and quadriceps active test.

 

Option C. MCL Injury. Valgus stress test is used to test the integrity of the MCL in cases of a suspected MCL injury.

 

Option D. LCL Injury. Varus stress test is used for LCL injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lachman test, a variant of anterior drawer test is used to test the integrity of the ACL in cases of suspected ACL injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is the SAFEST test to be performed in a patient with acutely injured knee joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lachman’s test

 

Option A)

 

TESTS FOR ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT:

 

  • Lachman’s test (most sensitive done at 20° knee flexion)
  • Anterior drawer test (done at 90° of knee flexion)
  • Pivot shift test/flexion rotation drawer test (2nd best)
  • Test for ACL in decreasing order of sensitivity and specificity:
    • Lachman’s test > flexion rotation drawer test > anterior drawer test > pivot shift phenomenon tested by lateral pivot shift test of macintosh or jerk test of Hughston and loose.
  • Lelli test – New test for ACL

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lachman test has a diagnostic accuracy for acute ACL ruptures (within 2 weeks of examination) of 77.7% sensitivity and >95% specificity. Thus, it is considered as the safest test that can be performed in case of an acute knee injury.

questions.text: In lateral blow to knee with fracture in intercondylar area, the structure injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ACL

 

Option B)

 

MECHANISM OF INJURY

 

  • Valgus force: MCL
  • Varus force: LCL
  • Backward force: PCL
  • Twisting injury: Medial and Lateral meniscus
  • Anterior: ACL
  • Combination of Valgus in Flexion with twist injures the structure in following order: MCL then ACL, and last menisci.
  • Abduction or valgus force at flexed knee with rotational component is most common mechanism causing ligament injury at knee and if all forces are combined, ACL is most commonly injured and if there is only rotational component, then it causes menisci injury (medial meniscus > lateral meniscus).
  • Thus, rotation with valgus causes ACL injury.
  • In this question, there is a point given – fracture at intercondylar, which is the site of insertion of ACL.
  • Hence, ACL is the answer.

 

Educational objective:
 

  • The ACL is inserted on the lateral intercondylar area of the femur. An injury or trauma to this area disrupts the ACL.
  • The mechanism of injury of the ACL is the non-contact valgus + internal rotation force.
  • This mechanism is also associated with partial rupture of the MCL or the menisci.

questions.text: Injury from lateral side of knee causing inner part of knee to bend leads to damage to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MCL

 

Option A)

 

MECHANISM OF INJURY

 

  • Valgus force: MCL
  • Varus force: LCL
  • Backward force: PCL
  • Twisting injury: Medial and Lateral meniscus
  • Anterior: ACL
  • Combination of Valgus in Flexion with twist injures the structure in following order: MCL then ACL, and last menisci.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • MCL injuries mostly occur after an impact on the outside of the knee, lower thigh or upper leg, when the foot is in contact with the ground.
  • The combined movement of flexion/valgus/external rotation will lead to tears in the fibres.
  • Mostly, the deep part of the ligament gets damaged first, and this may lead to medial meniscal damage or anterior cruciate ligament damage.

questions.text: A patient met with Road Traffic Accident and developed knee pain. Dial test was positive. Structure injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterolateral corner injury

 

Option D)

 

POSTEROLATERAL CORNER INJURY

 

  • The Posterolateral Corner (PLC) is a complex that includes the lateral collateral ligament (LCL), popliteus tendon, fabellofibular ligament, arcuate ligament, popliteofibular ligament, and the short lateral ligament.
     
  • Dial Test or Tibial External Rotation Test:
    • This is the test for posterolateral instability.
       
    • The tibia is externally rotated on femur first at 30 flexion and then at 90 flexion.
    • Comparison is made with the normal side.
    • An increase in external rotation of greater than 10 indicates pathology.
       
    • Increase in external rotation at 30 of flexion but not at 90 indicates an isolated posterolateral corner injury and at both 30 and 90 of flexion indicates injury of both posterior cruciate ligament and posterolateral corner.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medial collateral ligament injury. In case of a medial collateral ligament injury, a valgus stress test will be positive.

 

Option B. Medial meniscal injury. Apley grind test is used to evaluate the medial meniscus injury.

 

Option C. Lateral meniscus tear. McMurray test is positive in a lateral meniscus tear.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Dial test is positive in case of a posterolateral corner injury.

questions.text: In ‘bounce home’ test of knee, ‘end feels’ are interference. All are ‘end feels’ except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Empty

 

Option C)

 

  • End point in Bounce Home Test normally has hard (bony) or firm (cartilage) feel.
  • The rubbery feel indicates pathology (torn ACL or Menisci).
  • Empty feel is not seen.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In Bounce Home Test, from flexed position, the knee is suddenly extended and then, the end point feel on extension is compared.
  • The end point feel is generally hard or firm in this test.
  • A sponge block or rubbery feel indicates an ACL or meniscus injury.

questions.text: Which one of the following tests will you adopt while examining a knee joint where you suspect an old tear of anterior cruciate ligament?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lachman’s test

 

Option C)

 

  • Lachman test is the most sensitive test for anterior cruciate ligament tears, both acute and chronic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior drawer test. This test is used to evaluate for a PCL injury.

 

Option B. McMurray’s test. This test is used to evaluate for meniscal injury.

 

Option D. Pivot shift test. This test is used to indicate an acute and low grade ACL tear.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To examine a knee joint with an old ACL tear, Lachman Test is the most sensitive test that can be used.

choices.text: Tenderness over the medial epicondyle
Tendinitis of common extensor origin
Tendinitis of common flexor origin
Painful flexion and extension

questions.text: Tennis elbow is characterized by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tendonitis of common extensor origin

 

Option B)

 

TENNIS ELBOW

 

  • Lateral epicondylitis, also commonly referred to as tennis elbow, describes an overuse injury that occurs secondary to an eccentric overload of the common extensor tendon at the origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) tendon. 
  • Aside from degenerative changes, the histological findings include granulation tissue, micro-rupture, an abundance of fibroblasts, vascular hyperplasia, unstructured collagen, and lack of inflammatory cells (macrophages, lymphocytes, neutrophils) within the tissue. 
  • On examination, there is a point of maximal tenderness is over the lateral epicondyle, occasionally in a distal location about 1-2 cm from the lateral epicondyle itself. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tenderness over the medial epicondyle. This is seen in the golfer’s elbow.

 

Option C. Tendinitis of common flexor origin. This is also a characteristic of medial epicondylitis.

 

Option D. Painful flexion and extension. Flexion and extension of the elbow are not painful in tennis elbow. The pain occurs in movements which includes shaking of hands, wringing of clothes, gripping objects, turning a door knob, etc.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tennis elbow is characterized by tendonitis of the common extensor origin of the ECRB tendon.

choices.text: Internal rotation of femur over stabilized tibia
Internal rotation of tibia over stabilized femur
External rotation of tibia over stabilized femur
External rotation of femur over stabilized tibia

questions.text: Physiological locking involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal rotation of femur over stabilized tibia

 

Option A)

 

PHYSIOLOGICAL LOCKING

 

  • Physiological locking occurs in last 30° of extension when femur rotates medially (internally) over stabilized tibia. This is caused by quadriceps femoris muscle.
  • Unlocking needed to initiate flexion is carried out by popliteus muscle, which moves femur laterally on stabilized tibia.
  • Quadriceps is involved in physiological locking of the knee.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Physiological locking involves internal rotation of the femur over the stabilized tibia in the last 30 of knee extension.

choices.text: Full range of abduction

questions.text: Which movement is painful in Painful Arc Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mid abduction

 

Option C)

 

PAINFUL ARC SYNDROME

 

  • It is anterior shoulder pain in 60-120° of glenohumeral abduction.
  • This is seen in subacromial impingement syndrome.
  • While sitting or standing, when the patient is asked to abduct the shoulder, the patient experiences pain in and around the glenohumeral joint.
  • Once there is onset of pain, the patient is asked to continue the arm abduction as high as they can.
  • Once the patient reaches to 120 of abduction, the pain begins to reduce.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome involves pain in the 60-120° of shoulder abduction or mid-abduction.

choices.text: It is the tendinitis caused by inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons
Supraspinatus tendon is most often involved
Shoulder abduction in the arc of 60-120 degrees is particularly painful
Surgical decompression of the subacromial space is frequently indicated

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about impingement syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgical decompression of the subacromial space is frequently indicated

 

Option D)

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is mainly caused by the structural narrowing of the subacromial space leading to inflammation, irritation of the tendons passing through the space due to repetitive shoulder movements.
  • Shoulder impingement syndrome can be described according to the location of the impingement, as external or internal.
  • External, or subacromial impingement, results from a mechanical or physical encroachment of the soft tissue located within the subacromial space.
  • Internal impingement results when the tendons of the rotator cuff encroach between the humeral head and glenoid rim.
  • Internal impingement is most commonly associated with the supraspinatus and infraspinatus tendons.
     
  • Clinical features:
    • Pain upon lifting the arm or with lying on the affected side. 
    • Loss of motion
    • Night pain prevents from sleeping.
    • Weakness and stiffness secondary to the pain.
    • Pain is commonly located over the lateral acromion, frequently with radiation to the lateral mid-humerus.
    • Pain in 60-120 of shoulder abduction
       
  • Treatment:
    • Physiotherapy + NSAIDs
    • Local injection of steroids
    • Surgery if required for impingement syndrome or rotator cuff tears (especially in young individuals)

 

Educational objective: 

 

  • Impingement syndrome is the tendinitis caused by the inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons, mainly supraspinatus and infraspinatus.
  • The patient experiences painful shoulder abduction in the arc of 60-120.
  • The surgical decompression of the subacromial space is not much effective in reducing pain. It is recommended in case of severe, persistent pain with functional impairment that have not been reduced with conservative treatment.

choices.text: Fracture of greater tuberosity
All of the above

questions.text: Causes of painful arc syndrome is/are:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

PAINFUL ARC SYNDROME

 

It can be caused by:

 

  • Chronic supraspinatus tendinitis (most common)
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Partial (not complete) tears of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity
  • Subacromial bursitis

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common causes of painful arc syndrome are subacromial bursitis, supraspinatus tendinitis, and fracture of greater tuberosity.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of Unhappy triad of O’ Donoghue?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibular collateral ligament injury

 

Option D)

 

UNHAPPY TRIAD OF O’ DONOGHUE

 

  • O'Donoghue unhappy triad or terrible triad often occurs in contact and non-contact sports, when there is a lateral force applied to the knee while the foot is fixated on the ground.
  • This produces an abduction-external rotation mechanism of injury.
  • The O'Donoghue unhappy triad comprises three types of soft tissue injury that tend to occur simultaneously in knee injuries:
    • Anterior Cruciate Ligament Tear
    • Medial Collateral Ligament Injury
    • Medial Meniscal Tear 

 

 

O’Donoghue triad

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The O’ Donoghue triad or unhappy triad or terrible triad consists of injury to the ACL, medial meniscus, and the medial collateral ligament. It does not include the fibular (lateral) collateral ligament injury.

questions.text: Menisci to tibia connection is by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coronary ligaments

 

Option A)

 

  • The coronary ligaments of the knee (also known as meniscotibial ligaments) are portions of the joint capsule which connect the inferior edges of the fibrocartilaginous menisci to the periphery of the tibial plateaus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wrisberg ligaments. These are the posterior meniscofemoral ligaments that arises from the posterior horn of the lateral meniscus and attaches to the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle.

 

 

Option C. Arcuate ligaments. The arcuate ligament is part of the posterolateral ligamentous complex of the knee. It is a Y-shaped thickening of the posterolateral capsule, which arises from the fibular styloid and divides into two limbs:

 

  • Medial limb: Curves over the popliteus muscle to join with the oblique popliteal ligament
  • Lateral limb: Ascends to blend with the capsule near the lateral gastrocnemius muscle

 

 

Option D. Oblique ligaments. The posterior oblique ligament (POL) belongs to the medial supporting structures of the knee and is one of the five components of the posteromedial corner (PMC) of the knee. It is located posterior to the medial collateral ligament (MCL).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The connection between menisci and tibia is called coronary ligament.

choices.text: Medial meniscus is more mobile than lateral
Lateral meniscus covers more tibial articular surface than medial
Medial meniscus is more commonly injured than lateral
Menisci are predominantly made up of Type I Collagen

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ‘Menisci’ is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial meniscus is more mobile than lateral

 

Option A)

 

  • Medial meniscus is less mobile, more prone to injury and covers less area of the tibial articular surface in comparison to the lateral meniscus

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Medial meniscus is less mobile than the lateral meniscus.
  • Lateral meniscus covers more articular surface of the tibia than the medial meniscus.
  • Medial meniscus is more commonly injured than the lateral.
  • Menisci are predominantly made of type I collagen.

choices.text: Flexion and extension at the ankle

questions.text: Which type of injury causes more damage to the semilunar cartilage in the Knee?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotation on a flexed knee

 

Option B)

 

  • The twisting force (rotation) in a weight bearing flexed knee is the commonest mode of meniscal (semilunar cartilage) injury.
  • Medial meniscus is more frequently torn than the lateral.
  • The commonest type of medial meniscal injury in a young adult is the bucket handle tear. This is vertical longitudinal tear that is complete.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexion and extension at the ankle. Lateral ankle sprain injuries can occur during ankle dorsiflexion, in which the calcaneofibular ligament and anterior talofibular ligament tears may occur associated with excessive inversion and internal rotational movement, respectively.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The semilunar cartilage or the meniscus damage is caused by the rotation on the flexed knee.

questions.text: An athlete sustained an injury around the knee joint suspecting cartilage damage. Which of the following is an investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arthroscopy

 

Option C)

 

  • Arthroscopy is investigation of choice for damage to the structures of knee (intra-articular).
  • Arthroscopy is the gold standard for making diagnosis and arthroscopic repair or removal is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Plain x-ray. If the injury is restricted to the cartilage, it will not show up in a plain X-ray; it may be noted on an MRI.

 

Option B. Clinical examination. The clinical examination of a knee is addressed to evaluate three aspects: 1) patello-femoral joint/extensor mechanism; 2) articular (meniscal and chondral) lesions; and 3) knee instability. The diagnosis cannot be made only on the basis of the clinical examination.

 

Option D. Arthrotomy. An arthrotomy is a surgical exploration of a joint, which should include inspection of the cartilage, intra-articular structures, joint capsule, and ligaments. Although arthrotomy alone can be performed to evaluate and treat the contaminated joint space, arthroscopy allows more complete evaluation of the cartilage and the joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Arthroscopy is the gold standard investigation and treatment choice in suspected cases of cartilage injury of the knee.

questions.text: The primary pathology in Athletic Pubalgia is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abdominal muscle strain

 

Option A)

 

ATHLETIC PUBALGIA

 

  • Athletic pubalgia refers to chronic pain in the inguinal or pubic region in athletes that is noted primarily on exertion.
  • It is also called as Sportman’s Hernia or Gilmore’s Groin.
     
  • Pathology:
    • The primary site of pathology is the insertion of rectus abdominis on the pubis.
    • Abdominal component is believed to be the initial injury in athletic pubalgia that in turn causes subtle pelvic instability/anterior pelvic tilt which predisposes to injury to proximal adductors.
    • The conjoint tendon insertion and the adductor longus insertion on the pubis may also be involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Pain in inguinal/pubic region following exercise
    • Tenderness at the pubic tubercle (Adductor insertion tenderness)
       
  • Management:
    • Primary management is conservative (Rest, Ice, Anti-inflammatory medications, etc.)
    • Surgery is indicated if conservative therapy fails.
    • Nesovic’s operation (bilateral) is reserved for resistant cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rectus femoris strain. This is caused by sudden, forceful over-stretching and eccentric contraction of the muscle. It is seen in soccer and football players. It is associated with avulsion of AIIS. The patient presents with pain and tenderness on the anterior aspect of the hip and mid-thigh at muscle belly.

 

 Option C. Gluteus medius strain. Gluteus medius strain is uncommon but can occur in sports like running or football. It occurs due to repetitive force on the contracting muscle. The patient experience sudden sharp pain in the buttocks that may reduce over time.

 

Option D. Hamstring strain. Hamstring strains are caused by a rapid extensive contraction or a violent stretch of the hamstring muscle which causes high mechanical stress. Hamstring strains are common in sports with a dynamic character like sprinting, jumping, contact sports where quick eccentric contractions are regular. In soccer, it is the most frequent injury. It results in a sudden, severe pain in the posterior thigh. Also, a "popping" or tearing sensation is described. Sometimes swelling and ecchymosis are possible.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The primary pathology of athletic pubalgia is abdominal muscle strain, mainly of the rectus abdominis muscle.

questions.text: Mallet finger is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Avulsion of extensor tendon

 

Option B)

 

MALLET FINGER/BASEBALL FINGER

 

  • It is avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx.
     
  • Cause:
    • It may be due to direct trauma, but more often occurs when the fingertip is forcibly bent during active extension (i.e. sudden occurrence of passive flexion of distal interphalangeal joint).

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture of proximal phalanx. Proximal phalanx fractures can be epiphyseal or shaft fractures and can be intra-articular or extra-articular. They are most often the result of forced rotation, hyperextension or direct trauma.

 

 

Option C. Rupture of flexor tendon. Flexor tendon injuries commonly result from volar/palmar lacerations. This can occur with an accompanying neurovascular injury. Another mechanism is a rupture from its insertion caused by a forced extension during active flexion like in ball sports where a finger is forced into extension while it is being flexed or where a player grabs an opponent's shirt (jersey finger) or in activities such as rock climbing.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mallet finger is the avulsion of the extensor tendon of the finger caused by forceful flexion of an extended finger.

questions.text: Jersey finger is caused by rupture of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor digitorum profundus

 

Option A)

 

JERSEY FINGER

 

  • It is avulsion of FDP from distal phalanx.
  • There is hyperextension of a flexed finger as in finger trapped in a jersey.
  • Ring finger most commonly affected.
  • Treatment is surgical.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor digiti minimi. Rupture of only one slip of the FDS is extremely rare. Rupture of only one slip will result in retained flexion of both superficialis and profundus tendons. The ruptured one slip of FDS, like a partial tendon laceration, can cause triggering.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Jersey finger is caused by the rupture or avulsion of the flexor digitorum superficialis tendon from the distal phalanx.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a H/o Intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cauda equina syndrome

 

Option C)

 

CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME

 

  • The cauda equina is a group of nerves and nerve roots from the distal end of the spinal cord, typically levels L1-L5 that gives both motor and sensory innervation to the legs, bladder, anus, and perineum. 
     
  • Cauda equina syndrome (CES) results from compression and disruption of the function of these nerves and most often occurs when damage occurs to the L3-L5 nerve roots. 
     
  • It is a neurosurgical emergency as it can present with back pain radiating to the legs, motor and sensory dysfunction of the lower extremities, bladder and/or bowel dysfunction, sexual dysfunction and saddle anesthesia. 
  • Delay in diagnosis and management can lead to devastating life-long impairment.
     
  • Etiology:
    • The most common cause of compression in 45% cases is a herniated lumbar intervertebral disc. 
       
    • Other causes include epidural abscess, spinal epidural hematoma, diskitis, tumor (either metastatic or a primary CNS cancer), trauma (particularly when there is retropulsion of bone fracture fragments), spinal stenosis and aortic obstruction.
    • Rare cases are associated with chiropractic manipulation, placement of interspinous devices, and thrombosis of the inferior vena cava.
       
  • Cauda equina syndrome is rare.
     
  • It occurs in 3% of all disc herniations. 
     
  • Cauda equina syndrome is most common in young men, possibly due to compressive thoracolumbar trauma.
     
  • Clinical features:
    • Back pain and sciatica (in 97% patients)
    • Weakness and changes in sensation in the lower extremities - usually bilateral but can also be unilateral and asymmetrical
    • Bladder dysfunction (disruption of autonomic fibers results in either retention or incontinence in up to 92% patients)
    • Bowel dysfunction (retention or incontinence in up to 72% patients)
    • Saddle anesthesia or decreased sensation in the perineum (in up to 93% patients)
    • Sexual dysfunction (impotence in men)
    • Upper motor neuron signs like spasticity and hyperreflexia
       
  • The symptoms above when present in isolation, are neither specific nor sensitive for cauda equina syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pott’s spine. Pott’s spine or tuberculosis of the spine is caused by mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is usually secondary to hematogenous spread from a primary site, commonly lungs. The common site of involvement in the spine is the paradiscal region because the subchondral bone around the disc space is supplied by the paradiscal vessels. This infection leads to progressive vertebral destruction and kyphotic deformity of the spine. The patient typically presents with back pain. Rest pain is rare. Radicular pain can be the presenting symptom. Constitutional symptoms of weight loss and fever are less commonly associated (more common with pulmonary involvement). There can be a cold abscess in the affected region. Nerve compression can be secondary to vertebral body collapse, leading to exaggerated DTRs or sensory loss.

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a neoplastic proliferation of plasma cells affecting multiple organ systems. The patient may present with anemia, fatigue, bone pain that worsens on movement and in the night. The affected vertebra is collapsed or have a compression fracture. Symptoms of weight loss, nausea, muscle weakness and mental confusion may be present along with kidney failure, hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Bone metastasis. In bone metastasis, there is sparing of the intervertebral space. The symptoms of spinal canal invasion and spinal cord compression may be present. Pain is the most common presenting initial symptom in patients. The pain is aching and deep, often occurs at night. Also, if nerve involvement has occurred, the pain is sharp and shooting in a specific dermatomal distribution. When the tumor has extended inside the spinal canal, motor, and sensory weakness may become permanent.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The provided information about the patient’s symptoms of severe back ache with urinary incontinence with history of intervertebral disc prolapse, without fever or weight loss is suggestive of cauda equina syndrome.
  • Remember, bladder and bowel involvement is typical of cauda equina syndrome, and it is not associated with constitutional symptoms, rather it presents with disc prolapse and cord compression.

questions.text: All of the following are red flag signs of back pain except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Age between 35-50

 

Option D)

 

RED FLAG SIGNS OF BACKACHE – INDICATIVE OF FURTHER WORK UP AND MANAGEMENT

 

  • Thoracic pain
  • Fever and unexplained weight loss
  • Bladder or bowel dysfunction
  • History of carcinoma
  • Ill health or presence of other medical illness
  • Progressive neurological deficit
  • Disturbed gait, saddle anesthesia
  • Age of onset < 20 years or > 55 years
  • Prolonged steroid intake (> 4 weeks)
  • Radicular impingement

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Among the given options, age of onset of low back ache can be < 20 years or > 55 years. So, age between 35-50 years is not a red flag for low back ache.

questions.text: The investigation of choice to detect a prolapsed intervertebral disc is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

INVESTIGATION FOR LUMBAR DISC HERNIATION

 

  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is investigation of choice as it has the advantage of not using ionising radiation and has good visualizing capacities especially of soft tissue.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT scan. CT scan is often used to detect morphological changes. Thus, it is more commonly used to look for fractures.

 

Option C. Myelography. Myelography has a leass accuracy than MRI for diagnosing disc herniation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To detect a prolapsed intervertebral disc, MRI is the investigation of choice.

questions.text: H reflex on electromyography is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S1 Radiculopathy

 

Option D)

 

H REFLEX

 

  • The H reflex is basically an electrophysiologically recorded Achilles tendon stretch reflex.
  • It is performed by stimulating the tibial nerve in popliteal fossa.
  • It is recorded over the soleus or gastrocnemius muscles.

 

 

  • It is used most commonly to evaluate S1 radiculopathy or to distinguish it from an L5 radiculopathy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • H-reflex in electromyography is seen in S1 radiculopathy to distinguish it from L5 radiculopathy.

choices.text: Psychosocial factors of back pain
Clinical factors of back pain
Tuberculosis of hip

questions.text: Yellow flag signs are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psychosocial factors of back pain

 

Option A)

 

YELLOW FLAG SIGNS OF BACK PAIN

 

  • No further work up and management required
  • Psychosocial factors shown to be indicative of long-term chronicity and disability:
    • A negative attitude that back pain is harmful or potentially severely disabling
    • Fear, avoidance behavior and reduced activity levels
    • An expectation that passive, rather than active treatment will be beneficial
    • A tendency to depression, low morale, and social withdrawal

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Yellow flag signs are the psychosocial factors related to the back pain.

questions.text:
True about spondylolisthesis is/are: 

 

  1. Congenital defect of posterior arch
  2. Slipping of L5 over S1
  3. Progressive slipping
  4. Abnormal congenital development
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Option D)

 

SPONDYLOLISTHESIS

 

  • Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebra over the other.
  • It is most common at L5-S1 level where the L5 vertebra slips over the S1 vertebra.
  • It occurs due to fracture of the pars interarticularis.
  • Types of spondylolisthesis:
    • Degenerative: occurs from degenerative changes in the spine without any defect in the pars interarticularis. The facet joint and disc degeneration leads to instability and forward movement of the vertebra on the adjacent vertebra.
    • Isthmic: occurs due to defect in pars interarticularis. The cause is undetermined but can be caused due to microtrauma involving repeated lumbar extension.
    • Traumatic: occurs after fracture of pars interarticularis or facet joint following a trauma.
    • Dysplastic: it is congenital and secondary to variation in the orientation of the facet joints to an abnormal alignment. The facet joints align more sagittally than coronally .
    • Pathological: can be due to systemic causes like bone or connective tissue disorder or infection, neoplasm, or iatrogenic origin.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Spondylolisthesis is a progressive slipping of the L5 vertebra over the S1 vertebra.
  • In the dysplastic or congenital type of spondylolisthesis, there is a congenital defect in the posterior arch components of the spine i.e., the pars interarticularis. The defect can be the congenitally abnormal development of the posterior arch, leading to its fracture from repeated spinal movements.

choices.text: Tuberculosis affection of ulnar bursa
Pyogenic affection of ulnar bursa
Non-specific affection of ulnar bursa
Ulnar bursitis due to compound injury

questions.text: Compound palmar ganglion is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis affection of ulnar bursa

 

Option A)

 

COMPOUND PALMAR GANGLION

 

  • Compound palmar ganglion is chronic inflammation of common sheath of flexor tendon both above and below flexor retinaculum causing hour glass swelling.

 

 

  • RA and tuberculosis are the commonest cause.
  • Its incidence is uncommon.
  • The disease can progress and result in a gross destruction of structures around the wrist and hence, requires excision without delay.
  • The palmar synovial bursa, covered by a dense palmar fascia, is not a common site for tuberculosis. But once infected, it can cause inflammation of all tendon sheaths about the hand and wrist resulting in median nerve compression.  
  • It can also lead to destruction of underlying bones if left untreated.
  • Early recognition and complete surgical excision of the diseased tissue along with appropriate anti-tubercular therapy gives a better prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pyogenic affection of ulnar bursa. Pyogenic or suppurative flexor tenosynovitis is a severe bacterial infection within the closed space of the digital flexor tendon sheaths. It can cause necrosis of the tendons and devitalization of fingers. It alters the gliding mechanism and creates adhesions within the flexor tendon sheath, resulting in marked loss of finger movements. It can result from bloodstream infection but is generally caused by penetrating finger injuries involving the flexor tendon sheath. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacteria causing this infection. The detection of the 4 Kanavel signs on physical assessment has high sensitivity. A painful passive extension is the earliest sign while flexor sheath tenderness is the last sign to be detected. The presence of erythema, swelling, and tenderness over the thenar eminence in the palm raises the suspicion of the proximal spread of infection to the radial bursa. Patients with an infected ulnar bursa present with pain, swelling, and erythema over the hypothenar eminence.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Compound palmar ganglion is the chronic, tuberculous infection of the ulnar bursa.

questions.text: A patient gives a history of twisting strain and locking of the knee joint. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniscal tear

 

Option B)

 

  • There is classical history of twisting injury and locking so diagnosis is meniscal injury.
  • The twisting force (rotation) in a weight bearing flexed knee is the commonest mode of meniscal (semilunar cartilage) injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Avulsion of tibial tubercle. Tibial tubercle fractures are most frequently seen in sports that involve jumping activities. Injury may be caused by quadriceps contraction during knee extension while initiating a jump. Damage can also take place during landing when the quadriceps contracts and the knee flexes to absorb the impact of landing. The patellar ligament inserts on the secondary ossification center, which places the tibial tubercle at risk for an avulsion injury.

 

Option C. Tearing of lateral collateral ligament. The most common mechanism of injury is seen via a high-energy blow to the anteromedial knee, combining hyperextension and extreme varus force.

 

Option D. Tear of anterior cruciate ligament. A common and frequent injury mechanism is non-contact combined valgus and internal-rotation trauma. Therefore, ACL injuries are often associated with other ligamentous injuries, such as a (partial) rupture of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) or the menisci. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given history of twisting strain and locking of the knee joint is the most common mechanism of injury of meniscal tear.

choices.text: Proximal interphalangeal joint

questions.text: In trigger finger, the level of tendon sheath constriction is found at the level of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metacarpophalangeal joint

 

Option D)

 

TRIGGER FINGER

 

  • Due to stenosing tenosynovitis, the flexor tendon may become trapped at the entrance to its fibrous digital sheath.
  • The usual cause is thickening of fibrous tendon sheath or constriction of mouth of fibrous digital sheath (mainly A1 pulley) at the level of metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • A tender nodule can be felt in front of metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly involved level of tendon sheath constriction in trigger finger is the MCP joint of the finger.

questions.text: Increased Q angle predisposes to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral patellar subluxation

 

Option B)

 

  • Q angle provides a lateral vector to patella and is line between Quadriceps and Patellar tendon.
  • Increase in Q angle predisposes patella to lateral overload and makes it prone to subluxate or dislocate laterally.
  • It is best measured in 30° of knee flexion to centre patella in trochlea.
  • Its value is more in females (about 15°) than males (8-10°).
  • Vastus medialis balances this lateral vector especially vastus medialis obliquus.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Increased Q-angle predispose to the lateral subluxation of the patella.

questions.text: Unlocking of knee is caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Popliteus

 

Option D)

 

PHYSIOLOGICAL LOCKING OF THE KNEE

 

  • Physiological locking occurs in last 30° of extension when femur rotates medially (internally) over stabilized tibia. This is caused by quadriceps femoris muscle.
  • Unlocking needed to initiate flexion is carried out by popliteus muscle, which moves femur laterally on stabilized tibia.
  • Popliteus muscle sends few fibres into the posterior margin of lateral meniscus.
  • Thus, muscle contraction withdraws and protects the lateral meniscus by drawing it posterolaterally during flexion of the knee and medial rotation of the tibia.
  • Quadriceps is involved in physiological locking of the knee.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Locking of the knee is caused by the quadriceps femoris muscle while the unlocking is caused by the popliteus muscle.

questions.text: Cervical spondylosis is more common at:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C6-C7

 

Option C)

 

CERVICAL SPONDYLOSIS

 

  • It is a cluster of abnormalities arising from chronic intervertebral disc degeneration.
  • Like disc prolapse, it usually occurs immediately above or below the 6th cervical vertebral (in lower two segments C5-C6 > C6-C7 > C4-C5).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C1-C2 and Option B. C2-C3 are less commonly involved in cervical spondylosis.

 

Option C. C6-C7 are the second common sites for cervical spondylosis after C5-C6.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • C6-C7 is the most commonly involved site in cervical spondylosis.

choices.text: Most frequently results from an incidence of acute trauma
Causes compression of nerve roots to produce an upper motor neuron lesion in the lower limbs
Produces pain and paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the forearm and thumb when affecting the 6th cervical nerve
Most frequently affects the upper cervical vertebrae

questions.text: True about Cervical spondylosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Produces pain and paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the forearm and thumb when affecting the 6th cervical nerve

 

Option C)

 

CLINICAL FEATURES OF CERVICAL SPONDYLOSIS

 

  • 90% of men > 50 years and 90% of women > 60 years are affected.
  • Headache, neck pain and stiffness, worse in morning and improving throughout day, commonly located in occipital region and radiating to frontal area, back of shoulders, and down one or both arms.
  • Typically, patients have proximal arm pains and distal paresthesia.
  • Muscles of back of neck and interscapular region may be tender and neck movements limited.
  • X-rays reveal spur/osteophyte formation (or lipping) at the anterior and posterior margins of disc.
  • Treatment is usually conservative, patient education on physiotherapy, lifestyle modifications and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • Surgery is advocated for cervical radiculopathy in patients who have intractable pain, progressive symptoms, or weakness that fails to improve with conservative therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most frequently results from an incidence of acute trauma. False. Cervical spondylosis is an age-related degeneration of the intervertebral disc and cervical spinal elements. Degenerative changes in surrounding structures, including the facets joints, posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL), and ligamentum flavum all combine to cause narrowing of the spinal canal and intervertebral foramina. Consequently, the spinal cord, spinal vasculature, and nerve roots can be compressed, resulting in axial neck pain, cervical myelopathy, and cervical radiculopathy.

 

Option B. Causes compression of nerve roots to produce an upper motor neuron lesion in the lower limbs. False. Cervical myelopathy due to spondylotic changes leads to spinal cord compression and consequently upper motor neuron symptoms in the upper limb like spasticity, and hyperreflexia.

 

Option D. Most frequently affects the upper cervical vertebrae. False. Cervical spondylosis involves most commonly the lower cervical vertebrae i.e., C4-C5, C5-C6, C6-C7.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cervical spondylosis produces pain and paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the forearm and thumb when the 6th cranial nerve is affected.

choices.text: Injection of local anesthetic helps in diagnosis
Steroid injections are contraindicated
Painful arc of movement causes secondary weakness
Acromial beak of bone appears with age

questions.text: The following are True regarding Rotator cuff tendinitis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroid injections are contraindicated

 

Option B)

 

ROTATOR CUFF TENDINITIS

 

  • Rotator cuff tendonitis is an inflammation of the tendons that make up the rotator cuff, i.e., supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis.
  • This condition is often seen along with shoulder impingement and can present acutely following an injury or as a result of chronic, repetitive overuse activities.
  • The mechanical compression of the tendons can occur secondary to a degenerative bursa, acromial spurring, and predisposing acromial morphologies (i.e., the hooked-type acromion).
  • Painful arc of movement of the shoulder causes secondary weakness of the shoulder abduction movements.
  • To differentiate between a rotator cuff tear and tendinitis, some clinicians injects local anesthetic in the shoulder. In patients with tendinitis, the anesthetic agent relieves pain and the muscle strength appears to be normal.
     
  • Treatment:
    • Physiotherapy + NSAIDs
  • Local injection of steroids
  • Surgery if required for impingement syndrome or rotator cuff tears (especially in young individuals).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In rotator cuff tendinitis, there is painful inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons between the subacromial space.
  • The subacromial space can be narrowed by hooked acromion. The beak of the acromion appears with age.
  • The painful arc on shoulder abduction movement causes secondary weakness of the abduction movements.
  • The steroid injections are given for symptomatic relief into the subacromial space. This also helps with physiotherapy treatment in such patients.

questions.text: A patient sustained injury to his knee with a twisting force. On examination, pain is felt more on medial femoral side of knee than tibial side. Injured structure might be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial collateral ligament

 

Option C)

 

  • The most common mechanism of ligament disruption of knee is abduction (valgus), flexion and internal rotation of femur on tibia which usually occur in sports, in which the foot is planted solidly on the ground and leg is twisted by rotating body.
  • The medial structures, medial (tibial) collateral ligament (MCL) and medial capsular ligament are first to fail, followed by ACL tear if the force is of sufficient magnitude.
  • The medial meniscus may be trapped between condyles and have a peripheral tear, thus producing unhappy triad of O’Donoghue.

 

MEDIAL COLLATERAL LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • The medial collateral ligament (MCL) runs from the inside surface of the upper tibia to the inner surface of the bottom of the femur.
  • This ligament keeps the tibia in place.
  • The MCL is usually injured by pressure or stress on the outside part of the knee.
  • An MCL injury can be a stretch, partial tear, or complete tear of the ligament.
  • MCL injuries also often occur at the same time as an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.
  • Common symptoms of injury to the medial collateral ligament are:
    • Knee swelling
    • Locking or catching of the knee on movement
    • Pain and tenderness along the inside of the joint
    • A knee that gives way or feels like it is going to give when it is active or stressed in a certain way

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior cruciate ligament. The most common mechanism of ACL injury is a sudden pivoting or cutting maneuver during sports activity, which is commonly seen in football, basketball, and soccer. The ligament can also tear due to automobile accidents. At the time of the injury, a “pop” or “snap” can sometimes be felt or heard. The amount of pain experienced at the time of the injury is can be severe. Immediate swelling of the knee develops at the time of injury within the first few hours, but the extent of swelling can be limited if the knee is immediately iced or splinted. There is an inability to bear weight on leg along with an instability of the knee.

 

Option B. Posterior cruciate ligament. The PCL is usually injured by hyperxtension of the knee while landing after jumping. The PCL can also be injured from a direct blow to the flexed knee, such as falling hard on a bent knee. Most PCL injuries occur with other ligament injuries and severe knee trauma. Often, the knee is dislocated and the nerves and blood vessels are injured. The symptoms of the injury include knee swelling, tenderness in the popliteal fossa, joint instability and pain.

 

Option D. Lateral collateral ligament. A lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury is usually caused by pressure or an injury that pushes the knee joint from the inside, which results in stress on the outside part of the joint. The symptoms of a tear in the lateral collateral ligament can include knee swelling, locking or catching of knee with movement, pain or tenderness along the outside of knee, and a feeling of giving way.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • History of a twisting injury along with pain on the medial side of the knee is suggestive of injury to the medial collateral ligament.

choices.text: Varus/valgus stress test in full flexion
Varus/valgus stress test in full extension
Varus/valgus stress test in 30° of flexion
Varus/valgus stress test in 90° of flexion

questions.text: Structural integrity of collateral ligaments is tested by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Varus/valgus stress test in 30° of flexion

 

Option C)

 

  • Main test for MCL (medial collateral ligament) is valgus (abduction) stress in 30° of knee flexion (because in full extension, it is indicative of combined MCL, posterior oblique ligament injury and posterior cruciate ligament injury).
  • Varus (Adduction) stress test in 30° flexion (removes the lateral stabilizing effect of iliotibial band so that the lateral collateral ligament can exclusively be examined).
  • Apley’s distraction test is used for collateral ligaments.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The structural integrity of the collateral ligaments of the knee i.e., the MCL and the LCL, is tested by the valgus or varus stress tests in 30 of knee flexion.

questions.text: A twisting injury of knee in flexed position would result in injury to all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibular collateral ligament

 

Option D)

 

  • The most common mechanism of ligament disruption of knee is abduction (valgus) flexion and internal rotation of femur on tibia which usually occur in sports, in which the foot is planted solidly on the ground and leg is twisted by rotating body (i.e. football, soccer, basketball, skiing).
  • The medial structures, medial (tibial) collateral ligament (MCL) and medial capsular ligament are first to fail, followed by ACL tears if the force is of sufficient magnitude.
  • The medial meniscus may be trapped between condyles and have a peripheral tear, thus producing unhappy triad of O’ Donoghue.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common mechanism of injury of the fibular or lateral collateral ligament is a high-energy blow to the anteromedial knee, combined with hyperextension and extreme varus force.  
  • Twisting of a flexed knee leads to injury to the meniscus, capsule and the ACL.

questions.text: Most anterior to interspinous tibial plateau is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medial meniscus

 

Option D)

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Medial meniscus is attached anterior to the interspinous tibial plateau.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors increase the risk of Patellar dislocation?

 

  1. Genu varum
  2. Loose quadriceps femoris
  3. Ligamental laxity
  4. Femoral torsion with anteversion
  5. Lateral femoral condyle is shallow and hypoplastic
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

  • Recurrent dislocation Patella predisposing factors are:
     
  1. Hyperlaxity
  2. Genu Valgum
  3. External tibial torsion
  4. Patella too high or too low
  5. Under developed lateral femoral Condyle
  6. Weak medial ligaments/structures.
  • The patella dislocates almost always laterally.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Weak or loose quadriceps femoris, ligament laxity, femoral torsion with anteversion, shallow and hypoplastic lateral femoral condyle increases the risk of patella dislocation.

questions.text:
About recurrent dislocation of patella, choose the correct statement.

 

  1. Is associated with Genu Varum
  2. Is associated with Laxity of ligaments
  3. Common in persons with Shallow/underdeveloped medial condyle
  4. Is due to defect of vastus medialis
  5. Is associated with external tibial torsion
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

PREDISPOSING FACTORS FOR RECURRENT DISLOCATION OF PATELLA

 

  • Hyperlaxity
  • Genu Valgum
  • External tibial torsion
  • Patella too high or too low
  • Under developed lateral femoral Condyle
  • Weak medial ligaments/structures.
  • The patella dislocates almost always laterally.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Recurrent patella dislocation is associated with ligament laxity and external tibial torsion.
  • It is caused due to the defect in the vastus medialis muscle.

questions.text: Injury around the ankle joint occur due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inversion of foot

 

Option A)

 

ANKLE LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • Ankle ligamentous injuries, as classified by O’Donoghue, occur as minor ligamentous “stretch” injuries (type I sprain), incomplete ligamentous tears (type II sprain), or complete disruption of the ligament or ligaments (type III sprain).
  • The most common site of ligament injury is ankle joint.
  • The most common mode of ankle injury is inversion of plantar flexed foot.
  • Over 90% of the ankle ligament injury involves lateral collateral ligament usually the anterior talofibular ligament.

 

 

Ligaments around ankle

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common mechanism of injury to the ligaments of the ankle joint is the inversion of the foot along with plantarflexion.

choices.text: Lateral meniscus covers more articular surface of tibia
Lateral meniscus is more prone to injury

questions.text: All are true about menisci of knee joint except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral meniscus is more prone to injury

 

Option C)

 

Medial meniscus is more frequently torn than the lateral.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral meniscus cover more articular surface of the tibia and is semicircular in shape. It is more mobile, thus less prone to injury.

questions.text:
Locking of knee joint can be caused by:

 

  1. Osgood-Schlatter disease
  2. Loose body in knee joint
  3. Tuberculosis of knee
  4. Medial meniscal partial tear
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Option B)

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Locking of the knee joint can be caused by presence of loose bodies in the knee or the meniscal tear.

questions.text: Medial meniscus of knee joint is injured more often than the lateral meniscus because the medial meniscus is relatively:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Less mobile

 

Option B)

 

  • Medial meniscus is more frequently torn than the lateral.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Medial meniscus is more injured than lateral because it is less mobile.
  • The mobility is less due to its firmer attachment with joint capsule and medial collateral ligament.

questions.text: Sudden inversion of foot leads to rupture of which tendon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior talofibular ligament

 

Option B)

 

ANTERIOR TALOFIBULAR LIGAMENT (ATFL) INJURY

 

  • ATFL injury is the most common ligament injury in the ankle that can occur as part of the lateral ligament complex injuries.
  • The injury can comprise either tear, avulsion fractures or both.
  • ATFL injuries typically occur with an inversion injury to the ankle, either with or without plantar flexion. 
  • Approximately two-thirds of ankle sprains tend to be isolated injuries to the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL), the weakest ligament in the lateral collateral complex of the ankle. 
  • Avulsion is more common at the fibular end than at the talar end of the ligament.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deltoid ligament. Deltoid Ligament Injury causes pain around medial malleolus. The x-rays appear normal. The ligament has tibial attachment and the other expansions are into talus, navicular, calcaneum, spring ligament. The most common mechanism of injury is supination and external rotation or pronation and external rotation.

 

Option C. Posterior talofibular ligament. Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL) injuries are less common than other lateral collateral ligament injuries of the ankle and almost always occur with other injuries. One potential reason for relatively lower PTFL injury rates it is not a major stabilizer of the lateral ankle joint. PTFL injuries have been associated with talar dome ostechondral defect, calcaneofibular ligament (CFL) injury, ATFL injury, and ankle dislocation.

 

Option D. Spring ligament. Spring ligament injuries or calcaneonavicular ligament injuries refer to stretching sprains, tears, or ruptures of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament complex and can affect one or more of the three portions. Spring ligament complex injuries are most commonly associated with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction in adult acquired flat foot and are rare in isolation. Middle-aged women are most commonly affected.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sudden inversion of the foot leads to rupture of the anterior talofibular ligament, with or without foot plantarflexion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old professional footballer suffered a twisting injury to his right ankle. On examination, there is a lot of swelling around the medial malleolus but X-ray doesn’t show any fracture. The structure injured could be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deltoid ligament

 

Option A)

 

DELTOID LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • Pain around medial malleolus but normal X-rays.
  • It has the tibial attachment and the other expansions into the following structure:
    • Talus
    • Navicular
    • Calcaneum
    • Spring ligament
  • The most common mechanism of injury is supination-external rotation or pronation-external rotation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anterior talofibular ligament. ATFL injuries typically occur with an inversion injury to the ankle, either with or without plantar flexion. The x-ray in ATFL injury may show an avulsion fracture at the fibular end.

 

Option C. Spring ligament. A spring ligament tear can occur because of failure of the tibialis posterior tendon in adult-acquired flatfoot deformity or as an isolated injury with a normal tibialis posterior tendon. Plain radiographs may show flat foot deformity or evidence of hindfoot valgus. 

 

Option D. Tendo Achilles. Causes of Achilles tendon rupture include sudden forced plantar flexion of the foot, direct trauma, and long-standing tendinopathy or intratendinous degenerative conditions. Plain radiographs may show soft tissue swelling and obliteration of pre-Achilles fat pad (Kager's triangle).

 

Educational objective:
