  • Twisting injury of the ankle with swelling around the medial malleolus and normal x-ray are suggestive deltoid ligament injury.

questions.text: Commonest ligament injured in ankle injury:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior talofibular ligament

 

Option A)

 

ANKLE LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • Ankle ligamentous injuries, as classified by O’Donoghue, occur as minor ligamentous “stretch” injuries (type I sprain), incomplete ligamentous tears (type II sprain), or complete disruption of the ligament or ligaments (type III sprain).
  • The most common site of ligament injury is ankle joint.
  • The most common mode of ankle injury is inversion of plantar flexed foot.
  • Over 90% of the ankle ligament injury involves lateral collateral ligament usually the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL).

 

 

 

Ligaments around ankle

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Calcaneofibular ligament. This is the 2nd most commonly injured ligament after ATFL.

 

Option C. Posterior talofibular ligament. Injury to this ligament have lower rates, around 12%.

 

Option D. Spring ligament. Isolated tears of the spring ligament without associated Posterior Tendon tear are extremely rare and can present as an acquired flatfoot deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured ligament in the ankle injury is the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL).

questions.text: When the foot is in plantar flexed position, if it is suddenly inverted, which of the following ligament will be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior talofibular ligament

 

Option A)

ANKLE LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • Ankle ligamentous injuries, as classified by O’Donoghue, occur as minor ligamentous “stretch” injuries (type I sprain), incomplete ligamentous tears (type II sprain), or complete disruption of the ligament or ligaments (type III sprain).
  • The most common site of ligament injury is ankle joint.
  • The most common mode of ankle injury is inversion of plantar flexed foot.
  • Over 90% of the ankle ligament injury involves lateral collateral ligament usually the anterior talofibular ligament.

 

 

Ligaments around ankle

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior tibiofibular ligament. The PTFL is the strongest of the lateral ligaments, and extreme inversion with plantar flexion is required to place the PTFL under stress; as a result, the PTFL is less commonly injured.

 

Option C. Calcaneocuboid ligament. The mechanism of injury can be inversion +/- plantarflexion, or eversion.

 

Option D. Calcaneofibular ligament. Calcaneofibular ligament injuries typically occur along with an anterior talofibular ligament injury. The typical mechanism is excessive supination of the rearfoot on an externally rotated lower leg, leading to an inversion-internal-rotation type injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • With the foot in plantarflexion and sudden inversion, the ligament most commonly injured is the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL).

questions.text: The most common site for ligamentous injuries are those of the:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle joint

 

Option D)

 

ANKLE LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • Ankle ligamentous injuries, as classified by O’Donoghue, occur as minor ligamentous “stretch” injuries (type I sprain), incomplete ligamentous tears (type II sprain), or complete disruption of the ligament or ligaments (type III sprain).
  • The most common site of ligament injury is ankle joint.
  • The most common mode of ankle injury is inversion of plantar flexed foot.
  • Over 90% of the ankle ligament injury involves lateral collateral ligament usually the anterior talofibular ligament.

 

 

Ligaments around ankle

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Among the given options, the ankle joint is the most common site for the ligamentous injury.

choices.text: Distal end of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.text: Mallet finger is due to rupture of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Distal end of index extensor

 

Option B)

 

MALLET FINGER

 

  • It is avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Central extensor slip of finger. The central slip attaches at the base of middle phalanx, hence it is not involved in mallet finger.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mallet finger is caused due to the rupture of the distal end of the index extensor tendon.

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.text: A 30-year-old man involved in a fight, injured his middle finger and noticed slight flexion of DIP joint. X-rays were normal. The most appropriate management at this stage is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Splint the finger in hyperextension

 

Option B)

 

TREATMENT OF MALLET FINGER

 

  • An acute mallet finger should be splinted and the DIP joint is kept in hyperextension for 6-8 weeks.
  • Surgery is not advised even with fracture-dislocation, as the complication rate is very high and it is unlikely to improve outcome.
  • Old lesion need treatment if deformity is marked, hand functions seriously impaired, and joint still mobile. The options include fusion, tendon reconstruction or Fowler’s central slip tenotomy.

 

 

Stack splint or mallet hypertension splint for mallet finger

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Surgical repair of the flexor tendon. Surgery is not advised in this condition due to the related high complication rate and poor outcome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The ideal treatment for mallet finger is splinting the finger in hyperextension for 6-8 weeks using a stack or mallet hyperextension splint.

choices.text: Immediate treatment should include analgesics, muscle relaxants and back strengthening exercises
The appearance of the foot drop indicates early surgical intervention
If the neurological sign resolve within 2-3 weeks but low back pain persists, the proper treatment would include fusion of affected lumbar vertebra
If the neurological signs fail to resolve within 1 week, lumbar laminectomy and excision of any herniated nucleus pulposus should be done

questions.text: A previously healthy 45-year-old labourer suddenly develops acute lower back pain with right leg pain and weakness of dorsiflexion of the right great toe. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The appearance of the foot drop indicates early surgical intervention

 

Option B)

 

TREATMENT OF DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • Rest and Anti-inflammatory Medications: Continuous bed rest for 2 weeks.
  • If improvement is not complete, epidural injection of corticosteroid and local anesthetic may help.
  • Back strengthening should be started only after pain has subsided.
  • Operative removal of disc options are unilateral laminectomy/laminotomy or microscopic disc removal or endoscopic disc removal.

 

INDICATIONS FOR SURGERY

 

  • Absolute indications:
    • Bladder and bowel involvement (Cauda Equina Syndrome)
       
    • Increasing neurological deficit.
  • Relative indications:
    • Failure of conservative treatment—Up to 6 weeks of trial is usually given
       
    • Recurrent sciatica: 1st attack 90% recover
       
    • 2nd attack 90% recover; 50% recurrent consider surgery
    • 3rd attack 90% recover but all recurrent propose surgery
       
    • Significant neurological deficit with SLR reduction
       
    • Disc rupture in stenotic canal
       
    • Recurrent neurological deficit.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediate treatment should include analgesics, muscle relaxants and back strengthening exercises. Immediate treatment does includes analgesics and muscle relaxants to reduce pain but exercises are contraindicated in acute pain.

 

Option C. If the neurological sign resolve within 2–3 weeks but low back pain persists, the proper treatment would include

 

fusion of affected lumbar vertebra. Before carrying out any surgical procedure for an acute low back pain, at least 6 weeks of trial of conservative treatment methods like analgesics, rest and physiotherapy is recommended.

 

Option D. If the neurological signs fail to resolve within 1 week, lumbar laminectomy and excision of any herniated nucleus pulposus should be done. Bowel bladder involvement, increasing neurological deficit or failure of conservative treatment is an indication for surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In an acute low back pain presenting with weak dorsiflexion of great toe and foot drop symptoms, surgical intervention is the emergent treatment of choice.

choices.text: Between distal palmar crease and flexor crease of PIP

questions.text: In hand surgery, which area is called no man’s land?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Between distal palmar crease and flexor crease of PIP

 

Option C)

 

ZONE II

 

  • Situated between the opening of the flexor sheath (the distal palmar crease) and insertion of flexor superficialis (flexor crease of proximal interphalangeal joint).
  • It is known as ‘no man’s land’ or dangerous area of hand.
  • The results of flexor tendon repair is worst in this area because both superficial and deep tendons run together in a tight sheath and passes through three pulleys.

 

 

Zones of flexor tendon of hand

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The area between the distal palmar crease and flexor crease of the PIP joint is called the no man’s land in the hand surgery.

questions.text:
In a patient with L4-L5 disc prolapse, which of the following nerve roots can get compressed?

 

  1. L5
  2. S1
  3. S2
  4. S2-S4
  5. L4
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 5

 

Option C)

 

NEUROLOGICAL INVOLVEMENT IN DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • Usually, Lower Nerve Root is Compressed.
  • Central or paracentral disc herniation at L3-4 compress L4, at L4-5 compress L5, and at L5-S1 compress S1 nerve root.
  • Most unilateral radicular symptoms are due to paracentral/paramedian type disc herniation.
  • Far Lateral disc herniation of L4-5 compress L4 nerve root; of L5-S1 compress L5 nerve root (less common type and compresses the above nerve root).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the disc prolapse at L4-L5 level, the L4 and L5 nerve roots can get compressed.

questions.text: Most common nerve used for nerve conduction study in H reflex is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tibial nerve

 

Option C)

 

H REFLEX

 

  • The H reflex is basically an electrophysiologically recorded Achilles tendon stretch reflex.
  • It is performed by stimulating the tibial nerve in popliteal fossa.
  • It is recorded over the soleus or gastrocnemius muscles.
  • It is used most commonly to evaluate S1 radiculopathy or to distinguish it from an L5 radiculopathy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To elicit the H-reflex, posterior tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa is used in the NCV studies.

questions.text: In L5-S1, Nerve involved is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S1

 

Option C)

 

NEUROLOGICAL INVOLVEMENT IN DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • Usually, Lower Nerve Root is Compressed.
  • Central or paracentral disc herniation at L3-4 compress L4, at L4-5 compress L5, and at L5-S1 compress S1 nerve root.
  • Most unilateral radicular symptoms are due to paracentral/paramedian type disc herniation.
  • Far Lateral disc herniation of L4-5 compress L4 nerve root; of L5–S1 compress L5 nerve root (less common type and compresses the above nerve root).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In case of an L5-S1 disc prolapse, the nerve root involved will be the S1 nerve root, because usually lower nerve root is compressed, and paradiscal or central disc herniation is the commonest type.

questions.text: A patient has decreased sensation on tip of middle finger and decreased triceps reflex. This presentation can be linked to disc prolapse at:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C6-C7

 

Option B)

 

C6-C7 DISC PROLAPSE SYMPTOMS

 

  • Neck pain: on the back or side of the neck – can be mild/sharp/burning with tenderness on palpation
  • Radiculopathy: through the shoulder, arm, hand, or fingers – can be felt like hot or electric shock-like
  • Symptoms may worsen with some activities like playing a sport or lifting heavy weights or on head rotation or tilting
  • Neck stiffness and reduced neck movement.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C5-C6. This would compress the C6 nerve root, so the pain, tingling, and/or numbness may be felt on the thumb side of the hand. There may be weakness in the biceps and wrist extensor muscles in the forearm.

 

Option C. C8-T1. In this case, C8 nerve will be affected, so the patient will experience neck and shoulder pain. There may be paresthesia of the medial forearm, medial hand, and medial two digits along with weakness during finger flexion, in handgrip, and thumb extension.

 

Option D. T1-T2. Since this is an extremely rare condition to occur, most of the thoracic disc herniations are asymptomatic. Pain is the most common presentation and is usually located at the thoracic spine level with radiation. Other physical findings are unilateral or bilateral sensory loss, weakness of muscles, and bladder or bowel dysfunctions. T1 radiculopathy may be accompanied by C8 radiculopathy symptoms. Numbness of the 4th-5th fingers or weakness of intrinsic muscles in the hand. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • C6 nerve root supplies the thumb and the index finger while C7 supplies the middle finger.
  • So, disc prolapse at C6-C7 regions will cause sensory impairment at the tip of the middle finger, along with decreased triceps reflex.

choices.text: Prolapsed inter-vertebral disc

questions.text: The following X-ray was taken of a 50-year-old female with chronic backache. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spondylolisthesis

 

Option C)

 

SPONDYLOLISTHESIS

 

 

X-ray showing spondylolisthesis

 

 

AP view in spondylolisthesis
 

  • Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view, and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).
  • Difference between Spondylolisthesis and Spondylolysis:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spondylolysis. In this condition, the x-ray image shows Scotty dog sign on oblique radiographs which is a break in the pars interarticularis appearing as a collar around the dog's neck. Inverted Napoleon hat sign can be also seen.

 

 

Option B. Spondylosis. Spondylosis involves degeneration of the spine, presence of bony spurs or osteophytes.

 

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. PIVD presents with decreased intervertebral space.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The given x-ray image shows spondylolisthesis.

questions.text: Partial anterior dislocation of one segment of the spine over another is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

 

Option B)

 

SPONDYLOLISTHESIS

 

  • Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another.

 

 

Slip of one vertebra over the other

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spondylosis. It is the progressive degenerative changes that affects the cervical spine. It is a natural process of aging and presents in people after the fifth decade of life.

 

 

Option C. Kyphosis. Kyphosis is defined as an increase in the forward curvature of the spine, seen along the sagittal plane.

 

 

Option D. Scoliosis. Scoliosis is a condition in which the spine has an abnormal S-shaped curve seen over three dimensions.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The partial anterior dislocation of one segement of the spine (vertebra) over the another is called spondylolisthesis.

questions.text: Spondylolisthesis is most common at level:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L5-S1

 

Option B)

SPONDYLOLISTHESIS

 

  • Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another.
  • It nearly always occurs between L5 and S1 (most common) or L4 and L5.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. L4-L5. This is the second most common site of spondylolisthesis after L5-S1.

 

Option C. C5-C6. It is less commonly involved in spondylolisthesis than C3-C4 level.

 

Option D. C6-C7. Spondylolisthesis is a rare entity at this region of the spine.

 

Educational objective:

 

Spondylolisthesis is most commonly seen at L5-S1 level.

choices.text: Neural arch pars interarticularis

questions.text: In spondylolisthesis, there is fracture of vertebra in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neural arch pars interarticularis

 

Option B)

SPONDYLOLISTHESIS

 

  • Spondylolysis is a posterior defect of the vertebral body occurring at the pars interarticularis resulting from trauma or chronic repetitive loading and hyperextension.
     
  • If this instability leads to translation of the vertebral body, it is called spondylolisthesis. 
  • This process requires either a fracture or deformation of the posterior spinal elements resulting in elongation of the pars interarticularis.
     
  • Isthmic spondylolisthesis refers to a defect within the pars interarticularis usually from repetitive microtrauma.

 

 

(A) Oblique view of lumbosacral spine

 

 

(B) Spondylolisthesis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spinous process. They can be caused in case of trauma like falls, accidents, severe & sudden twisting/bending, or blow to the spine. Its fracture is not involved in spondylolisthesis.

 

Option C. Transverse process. Fractures of the transverse processes may result from direct blunt trauma (as in motor vehicle accidents), violent lateral flexion-extension forces (as in sports particularly football), avulsion of the psoas muscle or Malgaigne fractures of the pelvis. It is not associated with spondylolisthesis.

 

Option D. Body. Compression fractures of the vertebral body generally occur from too much pressure on them. This usually results from a combination of bending forward and downward pressure on the spine. For example, falling from a chair in a sitting position on the floor usually causes head to go forward and at the same time, buttocks hit the floor. This causes the spine to bend forward concentrating the pressure on the front part of the spine - the vertebral bodies. The fracture occurs when the bone collapses and the anterior part of the vertebral body forms a wedge shape. The cancellous bone on the inside of the vertebral body is crushed, or compressed.

 

Educational objective:

 

Spondylolisthesis involves the fracture of pars interarticularis.

choices.text: Complete tear of supraspinatus
Fracture greater tuberosity

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete tear of supraspinatus

 

PAINFUL ARC SYNDROME

 

It can be caused by:

 

  • Chronic supraspinatus tendinitis (most common)
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Partial (not complete) tears of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity
  • Subacromial bursitis

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the complete tear of supraspinatus, the patient is unable to lift the arm in flexion, external rotation and abduction due to severe pain. So, painful arc is not seen in this case.

choices.text: Flexor digitorum superficialis
Flexor digitorum profundus
Extensor carpi radialis brevis
Extensor carpi radialis longus

questions.text: Lateral epicondylitis of elbow begins in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor carpi radialis brevis

 

Option C)

LATERAL EPIOCONDYLITIS

 

  • It is chronic tendonitis of common extensor origin (esp. extensor carpi radialis brevis) on lateral epicondyle.
  • It may result in small tears, fibrocartilaginous metaplasia, microscopic calcification and painful vascular reaction in tendon fibres close to lateral epicondyle (degenerative changes with angiofibroblastic proliferation).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral epicondylitis is the inflammation of the tendon of ECRB (extensor carpi radialis brevis).

choices.text: Baseball pitcher’s elbow
Carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: Cozen’s test is used for the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tennis elbow

 

Option A)

TENNIS ELBOW

 

  • Cozen’s test:
    • Pain can be reproduced by passively stretching the extensor radialis brevis.
       
    • This is done by extending the elbow, pronating the forearm and then, passively flexing the wrist or active extension of wrist against resistance can produce pain.
    • The test is positive if there is pain on lateral epicondyle.

 

 

Cozen’s test

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Golfer’s elbow. In the passive provocative test for golfer’s elbow, the examiner palpates the medial epicondyle of the patient and passively supinates the patient’ forearm while fully extending the elbow, wrist and fingers with the other hand. If the patient experiences pain or discomfort, the test is considered positive.

 

 

 Option D. Carpal tunnel syndrome. Carpal Compression Test or Median Compression Test or Durkan’s test is a diagnostic test for carpal tunnel syndrome. With the patient in sitting or standing and forearm supinated, the examiner applies direct pressure over the carpal tunnel between the thenar and hypothenar eminence for 30 seconds. A positive test indicates numbness, pain or paresthesia in the nerve’s distribution.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cozen’s test is a provocative test used for the diagnosis of tennis elbow.

choices.text: Both of the above
None of the above

questions.text: de Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both of the above

 

Option C)

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • It involves tendon entrapment, thickening and myxoid degeneration of the tendon sheaths around the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.
  • While the exact cause of de Quervain tenosynovitis is unclear, it has been attributed to myxoid degeneration with fibrous tissue deposits and increased vascularity rather than acute inflammation of the synovial lining.

 

Educational objective:

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.

choices.text: de Quervain’s tenosynovitis

questions.text: Finkelstein’s test is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) de Quervain’s tenosynovitis

 

Option B)

DE QUERVAIN TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • Pathognomic sign is Finkelstein’s test.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful.
  • Repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Golfer’s elbow. In the passive provocative test for golfer’s elbow, the examiner palpates the medial epicondyle of the patient and passively supinates the patient’ forearm while fully extending the elbow, wrist and fingers with the other hand. If the patient experiences pain or discomfort, the test is considered positive.

 

 

Option C. Trigger finger. The patient is asked to actively open and close the fingers of the hand as in making and opening a fist. This will cause locking of the finger at a point.

 

Option D. Tennis elbow. The most commonly used test for tennis elbow is cozen’s test where the patient is asked to move the wrist in dorsiflexion with the elbow in extension and pronation, wrist in radial abduction, and hand in a fist, while the examiner applies resistance to this movement. This produces pain on the lateral epicondyle.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Finkelstein’s test is used to provocate the pain symptoms of de Quervain’s tenosynovitis.

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: Dupuytren’s contracture is fibrosis of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palmar fascia

 

Option A)

DUPUYTREN’S CONTRACTURE

 

  • Dupuytren’s contracture is nodular hypertrophy and contracture of superficial palmar fascia (palmar aponeurosis).
  • Dupuytren contracture is predominantly a myofibroblastic disease that affects the palmar and digital fascia of the hand, resulting in contracture in the hand.
  • The most commonly affected digits are the fourth and fifth digits.
  • The disease begins in the palm as painless nodules that forms longitudinally.
  • The nodules then forms cords that produce contracture within the fascial bands and tissues of the hand.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The palmar and digital fascia of the hand gets fibrosed and contracted in Dupuytren’s contracture.

choices.text: Incision and release
Subtotal fasciectomy + Skin transplantation

questions.text: The best treatment for Dupuytren’s contracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subtotal fasciectomy + Skin transplantation

 

Option D)

DUPUYTREN’S CONTRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Wait and watch is the usual treatment.
  • Primary indication of surgery is fixed contracture of >30° at MP joint or > 15° contracture at PIP joint.
  • Surgery does not cure the disease; it only partially corrects the deformity.
  • Usually done surgery is subtotal fasciectomy.
  • In this procedure, a zig-zag incision is made and the contracted tissue and cord(s) are removed to straighten finger. Zig-zag incisions allow the skin to heal without causing more contracture.

 

 

  • In some cases, the wound is left open to heal gradually on its own after fasciectomy.
  • In some cases, a skin graft is needed for wound healing.
  • For the skin graft, a healthy skin from another area of body is taken to seal the wound.
  • Post-op, a splint is required to be worn during recovery.
  • Closure may be done by Z plasty.
  • Severe or recurrent PIP joint disease may need arthrodesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fasciotomy. Needle fasciotomy is an outpatient procedure in which one or more fibrous contractures are sectioned using a blade or the bevel of a needle. Sectioning is achieved by moving the needle in a sawing motion against the fibrous band repeatedly until the band breaks, or until partial sectioning has been achieved and the finger can be extended causing the band to snap. Depending on the severity of the condition some individuals may require more than one session, particularly if there is contracture of the PIP joint. Based on the evidence, the main benefit offered by this procedure is a short-term reduction in the degree of contracture. Recurrence rate is approximately 50% at 3-5 years. Common complications reported in the studies include skin breaks, localized pain and nerve injuries. 

 

Educational objective:

 

The best surgical treatment for dupuytren’s contracture is subtotal fasciectomy with skin transplantation.

questions.text: Most common cause of trigger finger:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trauma

 

Option A)

CAUSES OF TRIGGER FINGER

 

  • Local trauma
  • Unaccustomed activity
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Gout
  • Amyloidosis
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Thyroid disease

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Localized trauma is the most common cause of trigger finger.

choices.text: There is collapse of medial longitudinal arch
The heel becomes valgus and foot pronates at the subtalar mid complex joint
Jack’s test differentiates between flexible and rigid deformity
Tarsal coalition is inherited as X-linked recessive condition

questions.text: All are true regarding pes planus except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tarsal coalition is inherited as X-linked recessive condition

 

Option D)

PES PLANUS (FLAT FOOT)
 

  • Flat foot refers to obliterated medial longitudinal arch.
  • Heel is often in valgus called as planovalgus.
  • Pes Planus is of 2 types: (Differentiated by Jack’s test)
    • Flexible: Disappears on non-weight bearing. Management is conservative.
    • Rigid: Due to Congenital Vertical talus or RA or Infection or tarsal coalition or tibialis posterior dysfunction. They often require surgical intervention.
  • Tarsal Coalition is autosomal dominant.
    • Fusion of tarsal bones (Talocalcaneal, calcaneonavicular and talonavicular)
    • Present at birth but becomes symptomatic later when fibrous connection becomes rigid bar.
    • Stiff flat foot (with spasm of peroneal muscles)
  • Diagnosis is by X-ray/CT scan (better)
  • Initial treatment is conservative.
  • If it fails, surgery by Excision of coalition bar or arthrodesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. There is collapse of medial longitudinal arch; Option B. The heel becomes valgus and foot pronates at the subtalar mid complex joint; Option C. Jack’s test differentiates between flexible and rigid deformity are all true about pes planus.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pes planus involves collapse of medial longitudinal arch, which causes the heel to go into valgus and foot into pronation at the subtalar mid complex joint.

 

Tarsal coalition in pes planus is autosomal dominant and not recessive. 

 

One of the most common type of tarsal coalition seen in pes planus is calcaneonavicular type.

 

Jack’s test is used to differentiate between the flexible and rigid flat foot. It is performed with the patient in weight bearing, with flat foot on the ground, and the examiner dorsiflexes the hallux to watch for an increased concavity of the foot arches.

questions.text:
Trigger finger occurs in: 

 

  1. Rheumatoid arthritis
  2. Trauma
  3. Osteosarcoma
  4. Osteoarthritis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Option C)

 

CAUSES OF TRIGGER FINGER

 

  • Local trauma
  • Unaccustomed activity
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Gout
  • Amyloidosis
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Thyroid disease

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trigger finger occurs commonly in rheumatoid arthritis and trauma

questions.text: Pulley involved in trigger finger:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A1

 

Option A)

 

  • Remember → A1 is at level of MCP

 

TRIGGER FINGER

 

  • Due to stenosing tenosynovitis the flexor tendon may become trapped at the entrance to its fibrous digital sheath.
  • The usual cause is thickening of fibrous tendon sheath or constriction of mouth of fibrous digital sheath (mainly Al pulley) at the level of metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • The A1 pulley is at the base of each digit where the digit meets the palm.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly involved pulley is the A1 pulley in the trigger finger.

questions.text:
True about Ganglion cyst:
 

  1. Most common in young male
  2. Contain synovial fluid
  3. Arise from extensor retinaculum
  4. It usually arises from the lunotriquetral joint
  5. Surgical treatment is excision of cyst
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 5

 

Option A)

GANGLION

 

  • More Common in Females.
  • It is most common soft tissue tumors (swelling) of hand and wrist.
  • It arises from leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath.
  • It is a unilocular cystic structure filled with mucinous fluid but without a synovial or epithelial lining.
  • It usually develops on dorsal surface of scapholunate ligament.
  • Back of wrist is the commonest site.

 

 

  • The three most common location of ganglion are:
  1. Dorsal wrist (from scapholunate joint > palmar wrist radioscaphoid or scaphotrapezial joint),
  2. Digital flexor sheath and
     
  3. Distal interphalangeal joint.
     
  • Age: 20–40 years.
     
  • Treatment:
    • Usually unnecessary and it may resolve spontaneously.
    • Aspiration to reassure the patient.
    • Pressure symptoms (e.g. Nerve) – removal.
       
  • Compound palmar ganglion is chronic inflammation of common sheath of flexor tendon both above and below flexor retinaculum causing hour glass swelling.

 

 

  • RA and tuberculosis are the commonest cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most common in young male. False. Ganglion cyst is most common in females.

 

Option C. Arise from extensor retinaculum. False. It arises from the leakage of synovial fluid from joint or tendon sheath. The most common locations are dorsal wrist, digital flexor sheath, and distal interphalangeal joint.

 

Option D. It usually arise from the lunotriquetral joint. False. Ganglion cyst arises from the scapholunate joint or palmar wrist radioscaphoid joint or scaphotrapezial joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ganglion cyst occurs commonly in females.
  • It contains synovial fluid.
  • It arises from flexor tendon sheath of digits.
  • It occurs on the scapholunate joint or palmar wrist radioscaphoid joint or scaphotrapezial joint.
  • Surgical treatment is excision of the cyst.

choices.text: Lesser leaguer’s elbow

questions.text: Olecranon bursitis is also called:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Student’s elbow

 

Option C)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tennis elbow. Also known as lateral epicondylitis, tennis elbow is an overuse injury secondary to eccentric overload of the common extensor origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon.

 

Option B. Golfer’s elbow. Golfer’s elbow or medial epicondylitis or pitcher’s elbow is the tendinopathy due to overuse of the medial common flexor tendon of the elbow.

 

Option D. Lesser leaguer’s elbow. Little Leaguer’s Elbow (Medial Apophysitis) affects young athletes, specifically baseball pitchers, whose bones are still growing. This condition is caused by overusing the elbow. Improper techniques can put stress on the arm’s growth plate, causing it to become inflamed and irritated. In severe cases, the growth plate may break away from the arm.


Educational objective:

 

  • Olecranon bursitis is also called as student’s elbow.

questions.text: In Pes planus, ligament stretched is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcaneonavicular

 

Option A)

PES PLANUS

 

  • In pes planus, the head of the talus bone is displaced medially and distally from the navicular bone.
  • As a result, the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament) and the tendon of the tibialis posterior muscle are stretched to the extent that the individual with pes planus loses the function of the medial longitudinal arch (MLA). 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In pes planus, calcaneonavicular or spring ligament is stretched along with the tendon of tibialis posterior muscle.

questions.text: Site of TB bursitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Trochanteric bursa

 

Option D)

TUBERCULAR BURSITIS

 

  • Tubercular bursitis is most common in trochanteric bursa (gluteal bursa) > bursa-anserine > compound palmar bursa > deltoid bursa > long flexor tendons.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prepatellar bursa. Tuberculous infection of the prepatellar bursa is a rare occurrence.

 

Option B. Subacromial bursa. There are a considerable number of cases of septic subacromial bursitis caused by non-specific organisms and rare cases caused by a tuberculous process. The reported cases of tuberculous bursitis in this location were mainly secondarily extended from the shoulder joint. Primary tuberculosis of the subacromial bursitis is quite rare.

 

Option C. Subdeltoid bursa. Involvement of the subdeltoid bursa is extremely rare.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common site of tuberculous bursitis is that of the trochanteric/gluteal bursa.

choices.text: Morrant Baker’s cyst

questions.text: Which of the following cysts is medially situated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bursa anserine

 

Option C)

BURSA ANSERINE

 

  • Bursa pes anserine is between tendons of sartorius, gracilis, semitendinosus muscles and tibial collateral ligament.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Housemaid’s knee. Housemaid’s knee or prepatellar bursa is located superficially between the skin and the patella.

 

 

Option B. Clergyman’s knee. Infraptellar bursitis is located just below the patella.

 

 

Option D. Morrant Baker’s cyst. Baker’s cyst is present on the posterior aspect of the knee.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Location of bursitis of knee:
 

  1. Prepatellar: superificially between the skin and the patella
  2. Infraptellar: inferior to the patella
  3. Pes anserine: medial to the knee
  4. Baker’s cyst: posteriorly in the popliteal foss

questions.text: Identify the abnormality shown in the following picture.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hallux valgus

 

Option A)

HALLUX VALGUS

 

  • It is outward/lateral deviation of great toe.
  • It is the commonest foot deformity.
  • Splaying of forefoot with varus angulation of 1st metatarsal predispose lateral angulation of great toe in people who wear shoes.

 

 

  • Overriding or under riding of 2nd toe can take place.
  • Metatarsus primus varus may be congenital or result from loss of muscle tone in forefoot in elderly.
  • It is also common in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Family history is obtained in 60%.
  • Elements of Deformity are:
    • Lateral deviation and rotation of hallux, with prominence of medial side of head of 1st metatarsal (bunion).
    • Prominence of 1st metatarsal head is due to subluxation of metatarsophalangeal joint.
    • There may be an overlying bursa and thickened soft tissue.
    • In long standing cases, metatarsophalangeal joint becomes osteoarthritic and osteophytes may develop.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hallux varus. It is characterized by the medial deviation of the great toe at MTP joint. More frequently, this deformity develops after a surgical procedure for hallux valgus because of overcorrection, excessive lateral release, over-resection of medial eminence, over-plication of the medial capsule, zero-degree or negative intermetatarsal angle, or immobilization of the toe in excessive varus after surgery. Other causes include trauma and certain systemic inflammatory diseases such as psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Option C. Rheumatoid nodule. Rheumatoid nodules develop over pressure points in rheumatoid arthritis. They develop along or within tendons in response to pressure and friction. These nodular growths are soft tissue enlargements that can vary in size. They are commonly located in the forefoot areas and often involve the same areas of both feet. Rheumatoid nodules are usually not painful but can cause problems like difficulty in wearing shoes, gait and balance abnormalities, and cosmetic issues.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The given image in the question shows the hallux valgus deformity which is the lateral or outward deviation of the great toe.

choices.text: Great toe points laterally
Great toe points medially
Lateral angulation of the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint
Dorsal angulation of the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hallux valgus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Great toe points laterally

 

Option A)

 

HALLUX VALGUS

 

  • It is outward/lateral deviation of great toe.
  • It is the commonest of the foot deformities (and probably of all musculoskeletal deformities).
  • Splaying of forefoot, with varus angulation of 1st metatarsal, predispose lateral angulation of great toe in people who wear shoes.
  • Overriding or under riding of 2nd toe can take place.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Great toe points medially. This occurs in hallux varus.

 

Educational objective:

 

In hallux valgus, the great toe points laterally.

questions.text:
Pes Planus is seen in: 

 

  1. Perthes disease
  2. Congenital vertical talus
  3. CTEV
  4. RA
  5. Infection
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

PES PLANUS (FLAT FOOT)

 

  • Flat foot refers to obliterated medial longitudinal arch.
  • Heel is often in valgus called as planovalgus.
  • Pes Planus is of 2 types: (Differentiated by Jack’s test)
  • Flexible: Disappears on non-weight bearing. Management is conservative.
  • Rigid: Due to Congenital Vertical talus or RA or Infection or tarsal coalition or tibialis posterior dysfunction. They often require surgical intervention.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pes planus is commonly seen in congenital vertical talus, rheumatoid arthritis, and infection.

questions.text: Osteochondritis in Kohler’s Disease affects which bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Navicular

 

Option C)

TYPES OF OSTEOCHONDRITIS

 

 

 

Osteochondritis in Kohler’s disease

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lunate. Osteonecrosis/osteochondritis of lunate is called as Kienbock’s disease.

 

Option B. Patella. The osteochondiritis of the lower pole of patella is known as Johanson-Larsen’s disease.

 

Option D. Femur head. The osteochondritis of femoral head is known as Perthes disease, which is seen commonly in pediatric population.

 

Educational objective:

 

The osteochondritis in Kohler’s disease affects the navicular bone due to lack of blood supply or late ossification of the bone.

questions.text: Microfracture technique is carried out for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteochondral defects

 

Option B)

TREATMENT OPTIONS FOR OSTEOCHONDRITIS DISSECANS

 

  • O’Driscoll ‘4R’ for treatment:
    1. Relief by physiotherapy and pain control modalities – few lesions can resolve over time
    2. Resect: Excision if small fragment
    3. Replace the joint surface
    4. Restore the cartilage lesion
  • Fixation with headless screws (Herbert Screw) and protected weight bearing till union.

 

 

Microfracture Technique:

 

  • If lesion < 2 cm2, Autologous Chondrocyte Transplantation i.e., cartilage cells are grown in artificial media and then transplanted into cartilage defect. 
  • Microfracture technique or abrasion arthroplasty: Making drill holes at the base of lesion causing regeneration of fibrocartilage and filling the defect of hyaline cartilage (in normal joint). Thus, it is substituting for hyaline cartilage by fibrocartilage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Non-union. Current treatment of non-union bone fractures involves surgery to stabilize the area and the insertion of a bone graft at the site to stimulate vasculogenesis and osteogenesis.

 

Option C. Tumors. Treatments for tumors include surgery to remove the tumor; chemotherapy to shrink the tumor before surgery or destroy lingering abnormal cells after surgery; immunotherapy; radiation therapy; and targeted therapy to slow or stop the growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis treatment can include medications to delay the disease progress and improve blood cell levels; physical and occupational therapy to develop motor and other skills; bone care with casts, splints; surgery to correct bone shape; and bone marrow transplant in certain cases.

 

Educational objective:

 

To treat osteochondral defects, microfracture technique is used which involves substitution of hyaline cartilage by fibrocartilage.

choices.text: Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle
Medial part of the medial femoral condyle
Lateral part of the lateral femoral condyle
Medial part of the lateral femoral condyle

questions.text: Most common site of osteochondritis dissecans is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle

 

Option A)

 

OSTEOCHONDRITIS DISSECANS

 

  • It is a poorly understood disorder, which leads to softening and separation of a portion of joint surface; resulting in development of small segment of necrotic bone in joint.
  • Knee (lower-lateral part of medial femoral condyle) is the most commonly affected joint. Elbow (capitulum) is 2nd common.
  • The cause is trauma either a single impact with the edge of patella or repeated microtrauma.
  • Patient is usually adolescent male, presents with intermittent ache and swelling, localized tenderness and Wilson’s sign (i.e., pain is felt in extension of flexed knee in medial rotation, but not in lateral rotation).
  • The best X-ray view is intercondylar (tunnel view – 30 degrees knee flexion).
  • MRI can make early diagnosis of cartilaginous lesions.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common site of osteochondritis dissecans is the lower lateral part of the medial femoral condyle.

choices.text: Fracture through neck of the talus
Fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

questions.text: Meyer pedicle graft is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-union fracture neck of femur

 

Option B)

SURGICAL TREATMENT FOR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE NON-UNION

  • Muscle-Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyer’s graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in the femoral head to augment vascularity.
  • Meyer’s muscle pedicle graft is used in the delayed presentation and non-union of the neck of femur fracture in adults.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture through neck of the talus. Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with Iliac crest cancellous bone graft is a reliable method for neglected non-union fracture of neck talus.

 

Option C. Fracture through the waist of the scaphoid. Free vascular graft can be used for scaphoid union.

 

Option D. Inter-trochanteric fracture femur. Valgus intertrochanteric osteotomy with fibular grafting is an effective procedure to achieve union in neglected femoral neck fractures in patients less than 60 years of age.

 

Educational objective:

 

Meyer’s pedicle graft of quadriceps femoris is used in the treatment of non-union of femoral neck fracture.

questions.text: Sectoral sign is positive in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Avascular necrosis of femur head

 

Option A)

SECTORAL SIGN

  • A characteristic sign of AVN of femoral head is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion.
  • This corresponds to the ‘Sectoral sign’ in which, with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed it is grossly restricted.
  • It occurs due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.

 

Educational objective:

 

Sectoral sign is positive in the AVN of the femoral head when the internal rotation is almost full during hip extension but restricted in hip flexion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man sustained posterior dislocation of left hip in an accident. Dislocation was reduced after 3 days. He started complaining of pain in left hip after 6 months. X-ray of the pelvis was normal. The most relevant investigation at this stage will be:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRI of hip

 

Option D)

INVESTIGATION FOR HIP PAIN

Hip dislocation can cause long term complications like AVN of the femoral head, early degenerative OA hip, nerve injury or myositis ossificans of the hip.

AVN is most likely to occur within 2 years of hip dislocation and is most commonly seen.

To rule out the cause of hip pain months after trauma, MRI remains an investigation of choice. 

  • MRI shows characteristic increased intensity in the marrow long before the appearance of X-ray signs.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for AVN hip which shows double line sign.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ultrasonography of hip. It is not usually involved in the assessment of AVN of hip.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most relevant investigation in a case of hip pain after traumatic hip dislocation is the MRI of the hip.

choices.text: Stress fracture of neck of femur

questions.text: A woman of 45 years of age, a known cause of pemphigus vulgaris on a regular treatment with controlled primary disease presented with pain in the right hip and knee. Examination revealed no limb length discrepancy but the patient has tenderness in the Scarpa’s triangle and limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the right hip joint as compared to the other side. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Avascular necrosis of femoral head

 

Option B)

AVN OF HIP

  • This patient is on steroids indirectly indicated by pemphigus vulgaris taking treatment (steroid is the preferred drug).
  • Pain in hip and knee (pain of hip can refer to knee because of common nerve obturator giving a twig to both joints)
  • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation, indicates altered shape of femoral head so, it indicates Avascular necrosis of femoral head.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stress fracture of neck of femur. In Stress fracture, there is no limitation of abduction and internal rotation.

 

Option C. Perthes disease and Option D. Transient synovitis of hip. Perthes (4-8 years) and transient synovitis (6-12 years) will not be considered in this age group.

 

Educational objective:

 

The given clinical presentation of hip pain without leg length discrepancy, scarpa’s triangle tenderness, and limited abduction and internal rotation of the hip; and history of treatment of pemphigus vulgaris with steroids, points towards the diagnosis of avascular necrosis of the hip.

choices.text: Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in patella
Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in tibia
Apophysitis of quadriceps tendon as it inserts in patella
Apophysitis of hamstring tendon as it inserts in tibia

questions.text: Jumper’s knee is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in patella

 

Option A)

 

JUMPER’S KNEE

 

  • Jumper’s knee (Patellar tendonitis) is seen due to inflammation of patellar tendon as it inserts into patella.
  • It is caused by small tears in the patellar tendon as it inserts in patella, that mainly occurs in sports requiring strenuous jumping and results in localized patellar tendon tenderness.
  • The tears are typically caused by accumulated stress on the patellar tendon.
  • The condition has a male predominance, with a more common occurrence in adolescents and young adults.
  • Patellar tendinopathy shares common signs and symptoms of other knee pathologies, such as pain with prolonged sitting, squatting, and stair climbing.
  • Also, patients may complain of pain from activities that involve prolonged flexion of the knee, otherwise known as the " Movie Theatre sign." 
  • Sudden tendon pain occurs with loading and usually stops almost immediately when the load is removed.
  • Rarely a patient feels pain when they are resting.
  • Examination of the knee reveal a localized swelling overlying the patellar tendon, which is tender to palpate.
  • Treatment mainly revolves around conservative measures such as reducing activities that place a loading impact on the knee.
  • Once the pain subsides, restoration of function is achieved through physical and exercise therapy. 
  • Surgery usually remains the last resort for chronic refractory cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in tibia. This is known as Osgood-Schlatter Disease. It is a condition where the patellar tendon insertion on the tibial tuberosity is inflamed. It occurs in late childhood, characterized by pain and bony prominence over the tibial tuberosity. The pain is usually exacerbated by physical activities like running, jumping, and climbing stairs. In the acute stage, the margins of the patellar tendon become blurred in radiographs due to the soft tissue swelling. After three to four months, bone fragmentation at the tibial tuberosity is viewed. In the sub-acute stage, soft tissue swelling resolves, but the bony ossicle remains. In the chronic stage, the bone fragment may fuse with the tibial tuberosity which can appear normal. The primary goal in the treatment is the reduction of pain and swelling over the tibial tuberosity. The patient should limit physical activities until the symptoms are resolved.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in patella is known as Jumper’s knee or patellar tendonitis.

choices.text: Lateral view X-ray

questions.text: In Spondylolisthesis, which of the following is NOT a useful investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anteroposterior X-ray

 

Option A)

 

IMAGING IN SPONDYLOLISTHESIS

 

  • Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view, and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).
  • AP view will show changes only in last stages – Inverted Napoleon Hat sign.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In spondylolisthesis, AP view of the x-ray is not useful as it does not show early changes in the spine alignment.
  • Lateral and oblique x-ray views are helpful in making diagnosis and decide for management options.
  • CT and MRI are required in all cases.

choices.text: Inferior articular facet
Superior articular facet
All of the above

questions.text: In cervical spondylosis, which part of vertebral body is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF CERVICAL SPONDYLOSIS

 

  • Degeneration of disc (loss of water and proteoglycan) cause decrease of disc height (hard disc) and converging of disc space causing:
  1. Segmental instability resulting in facet joint arthropathy and hypertrophic osteophyte formation by uncovertebral joint of Luschka. These spurs result in compression of existing nerve root (in intervertebral foramen) and later the spinal cord (in spinal canal).
  2. Buckling of ligamentum flavum and narrowing of spinal canal
  3. Ligamentous instability
  4. Radiculopathy (more common), myelopathy or both may be seen secondarily

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In cervical spondylosis, the degenerative changes occur in all parts of the vertebra, including the inferior and superior articular facets, pars interarticularis, end plates, and intervertebral discs.

questions.text: Which activity will be difficult to perform for a patient with an anterior cruciate deficient knee joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Walk downhill

 

Option A)

 

 

MRI knee sagittal view

 

ACL

  • It is intracapsular, extrasynovial
  • It is major stabilizer of knee.
  • Its mechanism is to stabilize internal rotation and extension of tibia on femur.
  • Its function is multiple in that it limits forward gliding of tibia on femur and limits hyperextension.
  • It makes a significant contribution to lateral stability and limits anterolateral rotation of tibia on femur.
  • It is injured by occurrence of excessive movements which it limits.
  • Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is most important for walking downhill.
  • Tests for Anterior Cruciate Ligament:
  • Lachman’s test (most sensitive done at 20° knee flexion)
  • Anterior drawer test (done at 90° of knee flexion)
  • Pivot shift test/flexion rotation drawer test (2nd best)
  • Test for ACL in decreasing order of sensitivity and specificity:
    • Lachman’s test > flexion rotation drawer test > anterior drawer test > pivot shift phenomenon tested by lateral pivot shift test of macintosh or jerk test of Hughston and loose.
    • Lelli test (New test for ACL)
  • Treatment of ACL tear: Arthroscopic ACL reconstruction with hamstring graft (Remember ligaments are usually reconstructed not repaired).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In an ACL deficient knee, the downhill walking is painful and thus, reduced.

questions.text: Positive pivot shift test in knee is because of injury to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior cruciate ligament

 

Option A)

 

TESTS FOR ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT

 

  • Lachman’s test (most sensitive done at 20° knee flexion)
  • Anterior drawer test (done at 90° of knee flexion)
  • Pivot shift test/flexion rotation drawer test (2nd best)
  • Test for ACL in decreasing order of sensitivity and specificity:
    • Lachman’s test > flexion rotation drawer test > anterior drawer test > pivot shift phenomenon tested by lateral pivot shift test of macintosh or jerk test of Hughston and loose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior cruciate ligament. In PCL injury, posterior drawer test is positive.

 

Option C. Medial meniscus. Apley grind test is positive in the medial meniscus injury.

 

Option D. Lateral meniscus. McMurray test is positive in a lateral meniscus tear.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The pivot shift is a dynamic test of knee stability, carried out by the examiner passively.
  • The movement is a combination of axial load and valgus force, applied by the examiner, during knee flexion from an extended position.
  • When the test is positive, it indicates an injury of the anterior cruciate ligament.

questions.text:
Following are the tests done for medial meniscal tear: 

 

  1. McMurray’s test
  2. Lachman test
  3. Apley’s grinding test
  4. Ege’s test
  5. Pivot shift test
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

Option C)

 

In case of a medial meniscus tear, following tests appear to be positive on clinical evaluation:

 

  • McMurray’s test
  • Apley’s grinding test
  • Difficult to perform full squatting and Toe walk in squatting position (Payr’s sign)
  • Steinmann tenderness test
  • Thessaly test
  • Ege’s test (weight bearing McMurray test)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • McMurray’s test, Apley’s Grinding test and Ege’s test are positive on examination of the medial meniscus tear.

questions.text: A young boy presents with swollen knee on getting hit over lateral aspect of knee and there was a twist while playing. Joint line tenderness was present. Anterior Drawer test done was negative. X-ray shows no fracture. Which structure is most likely to be damaged in the person?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medial Meniscus

 

Option B)

 

  • Joint line tenderness goes towards medial meniscus (most sensitive).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • History of a twisting of the knee and a blow to the lateral aspect of the knee are suggestive of medial meniscus injury.

questions.text: Which of the following structure are not normally visualized during the arthroscopy of the knee?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collateral ligaments

 

Option C)

 

  • They are extra-articular structure.
  • The menisci are commonly visualized from the medial/lateral knee sides.
  • The femoral cartilage and the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) are imaged from the anterior knee compartment; while the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) from the posterior knee compartment.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Collateral ligaments are not visualized normally during the knee arthroscopy because they are extra-articular structures.

choices.text: To see the posterior cruciate ligament
To see the anterior portion of lateral meniscus
To see the periphery of the posterior horn of medial meniscus

questions.text: Anterolateral arthroscopy of knee is for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) To see patellofemoral articulation

 

Option A)

 

STANDARD PORTALS IN KNEE ARTHROSCOPY

 

  1. Anterolateral portal:
  • Almost all the structures within the knee joint can be seen except the posterior cruciate ligament, the anterior portion of the lateral meniscus, and the periphery of the posterior horn of the medial meniscus in tight knees.
  • Located 1 cm above the joint line, 1 cm lateral to the margin of the patellar tendon.

 

  1. Anteromedial portal:
  • Used for additional viewing of lateral compartment and insertion of probe for palpation of medial and lateral compartment structures.
  • Placed 1 cm above the medial joint line, 1 cm inferior to the tip of patella, and 1 cm medial to the edge of the patella.

 

  1. Posteromedial portal:

  • Located on the soft triangular soft spot formed by the posteromedial edge of the femoral condyle and the posteromedial edge of tibia.

  • Used for viewing the posteromedial structures and for repair or removal of the displaced posterior horn of meniscal tears and for posteromedial loose body removal.

 

  1. Superolateral portal:

  • Used for diagnostically viewing the dynamics of patella-femoral joint, excision of medial plica.

  • Located just lateral to the quadriceps tendon and about 2.5 cm superior to the superolateral corner of patella.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anterolateral arthroscopy of the knee is done to see the patellofemoral articulation.

questions.text: Patient presents with knee problem. He gives history of injury while playing hockey 3 months back. On testing, knee was unstable anteriorly in extension but was stable in 90 degrees of flexion. Probably the injury involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ACL posterolateral fiber

 

Option B)

 

  • The ACL ligament is the primary restraint to anterior tibial displacement, accounting for approximately 85% of the resistance to the anterior drawer test when the knee is at 90° of flexion and neutral rotation.
  • Selective sectioning of the ACL has shown that the anteromedial band is tight in flexion, providing the primary restraint, whereas the posterolateral bulky portion of this ligament is tight in extension.
  • The posterolateral bundle provides the principal resistance for hyperextension.
  • Thus, complete tear will have instability in both flexion and extension.
  • Thus, anteromedial tear will have instability in flexion only and posterolateral tear will have instability only in extension.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Injury to the posterolateral fibers of the ACL leads to instability of the knee anteriorly in extension as these fibers provide resistance to hyperextension of the knee.

questions.text: Locking of knee can be due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both

 

Option C)

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pathological locking of the knee can be caused by the meniscal tear or by the presence of a loose body in the knee.

choices.text: Movement of tibial tuberosity towards medial border of patella
Movement of tibial tuberosity towards lateral border of patella
Movement of tibial tuberosity towards center of patella

questions.text: An athlete is sitting on the edge of table with knees flexed at 90 degrees. When he extends his knee fully, what will happen to the tibial tuberosity in relation to patella?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Movement of tibial tuberosity towards lateral border of patella

 

Option C)

 

  • If knee is extended from flexed position, tibial tuberosity moves toward lateral border of patella.
  • Knee extension from flexion with foot off the ground is called as open chain movement and there occurs external rotation of tibia hence, tibial tuberosity moves toward lateral border of patella. This is modified Helfet test.
  • Knee extension from flexion with foot on the ground is called as closed chain movement and there occurs internal rotation of femur causing center of patella to move medially hence, tibial tuberosity moves toward lateral border of patella. This may be blocked with meniscal injury.

 

 

Helfet Test

 

Educational objective:

 

  • When a person extends the knee completely, the tibial tuberosity moves towards the lateral border of the patella due to the external rotation of the tibia.

questions.text: It is wise to keep and repair the meniscus rather than removing it when the injury is to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral part of meniscus

 

Option C)

  • Meniscal Repair is recommended for tears in the Red zone and the Red white zone (Periphery).
  • Meniscal Repair is not recommended for tears in the white zone (Inner zone).
  • Tear of the inner zone are treated with arthroscopic excision.

 

Educational objective:

  • A tear in the peripheral part of the meniscus must be repaired and not removed because this is the red zone i.e., the vascular zone of the meniscus. Tears or surgery in this part can heal easily.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy was playing football when he suddenly twisted his knee on the ankle and fell down. He got up after 10 minutes and again started playing, but next day his knee was swollen and he could not move it. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial meniscus tear

 

Option A)

 

  • This boy has:
  1. History of twisting injury to the knee
  2. Swelling appearing next day due to effusion
  • This is classical to the medial meniscal injury.
  • In ACL injury, swelling appears immediately due to hemarthrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anterior cruciate ligament tear. ACL injury also occurs following a twist or internal rotation trauma. The swelling in this case appears immediately due to hemarthrosis.

 

Option C. Medial collateral ligament injury. MCL is also injured due to twisting force with knee in valgus, flexion and internal rotation of the femur on tibia while the foot is planted on ground. The swelling in this case appears immediately towards the medial side of the knee.

 

Option D. Posterior cruciate ligament. It is injured when the knee is flexed with posterior dislocation of tibia. Swelling in this case occurs 2-3 hours after the injury.

 

Educational objective:
 

  • The given history of sudden twisting of knee on ankle and presence of swelling on the next day with inability to move the knee are suggestive of medial meniscus injury.

questions.text: Commonest dangerous complication of posterior dislocation of knee is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popliteal artery injury

 

Option A)

  • Complications of posterior dislocation of knee includes ligamentous and meniscal injuries, in addition to popliteal artery, popliteal vein, and peroneal nerve injuries.
  • Concurrent popliteal artery injury has been reported to be 10-40%.
  • This can cause a potential risk for limb amputation.
  • Arteriography should be performed for knee dislocations, suspicious for any popliteal arterial injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sciatic nerve injury. Sciatic nerve is injured in cases of traumatic hip fracture-dislocations.

 

Option C. Ischemia of lower leg compartment. This can be caused following a traumatic crush injury or fracture or muscle rupture.

 

Option D. Femoral artery injury. Femoral artery is injured in cases of trauma by bicycle (handlebar injury).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most dangerous complication of posterior knee dislocation is popliteal artery rupture as it can lead to limb amputation.

questions.text: Which is the investigation of choice for a sport injury of the knee?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arthroscopy

 

Option D)

  • The usual protocol for sports injury in a suspected case is to diagnose the injury by MRI and if diagnosis is in doubt then, arthroscopy can confirm the lesion.
  • Arthroscopy is investigation of choice for damage to the structures of knee (intra-articular).
  • Arthroscopy is the gold standard for making diagnosis and arthroscopic repair or removal is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ultrasonography. Ultrasonography is a valuable imaging method to evaluate for sports injuries. In the lower extremity, ankle sprains, muscle injury and groin pain are the most common problems benefiting from imaging. Tendinopathy, tendon injury and ligament injury are well visualised in the hip, knee, ankle and foot by diagnostic ultrasound.

 

Option B. Plain radiography. If the injury is restricted to the cartilage, it will not show up in a plain X-ray; it may be noted on an MRI.

 

Option C. Arthrography. At present, conventional MR imaging of the knee has completely replaced conventional arthrography for the evaluation of internal derangement of the knee. CT or MR arthrography is used for meniscus injury evaluation in cases where the conventional MRI or CT are contraindicated.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Arthroscopy is the investigation of choice in cases of sports injury of the knee.

questions.text: Bucket handle tear at knee joint is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Injury to menisci

 

Option D)

 

MENISCI INJURY

 

  • The commonest type of medial meniscal injury in a young adult is the bucket handle tear.
  • This is vertical longitudinal tear of medial menisci that is complete.
  • In bucket handle tear, the inner part of the torn meniscus is displaced centrally.
  • This can also be associated with ACL tears.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Injury to medial collateral ligament. This can present as swelling on the medial side of the knee and opening of the medial joint space on plain radiograph.

 

Option B.  Injury to lateral collateral ligament. This can present as pain and swelling on the lateral side of the knee.

 

Option C. Injury to ligamentum patellae. This may present as loss of soft tissue margin of patellar tendon, increased density of infrapatellar fat pad, angulation and wavy soft tissue margin of patellar tendon, and patella alta.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bucket handle tear is seen in the medial meniscus injury of the knee.

questions.text: Most common cause of non-insertional tendonitis of tendoachilles is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Runners and jumpers

 

Option C)

 

ACHILLES TENDONITIS

 

  • Vascularity is supplied to the tendon through the paratenon on the deep surface of the tendon.
  • There are arterial branches within the gastrocnemius-soleus complex proximally, and small interosseous vessels at the insertion of the tendon distally.
  • There is a zone of relative avascularity 2-6 cm proximal to its insertion into the calcaneus (Watershed for circulation).
  • The vascular arrangement for the Achilles tendon is satisfactory for the low demand of the tendon sites in normal conditions.
  • However, increased demand from excessive use or overuse may lead to inadequate vascular supply and subsequent degeneration and fibrosis of the involved segment of tendon.
     

a. Insertional tendonitis:

  • Involves insertion site
  • May be associated with retrocalcaneal bursitis, and large exostosis on posterosuperior aspect of calcaneal tuberosity called as Haglund deformity or pump bump.
  • Overuse is the cause.
     

b. Non-insertional tendonitis with or without peri-tendinitis (more common than insertional tendonitis)

  • Involves water shed area of circulation (2-6 cm above the insertion)
  • Seen in runners and jumpers
  • It is also the commonest site of TA rupture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Overuse. Overuse of the tendoachilles leads to insertional tendonitis of the tendon.

 

Option B. Improper shoe wear. Improper footwear most commonly causes plantar fasciitis.

 

Option D. Steroid injections. Significant side effects have been reported with the use of corticosteroid injections as they can lead to tendon degeneration and rupture. It can inhibit tendon repair, delay tendon sheath healing, and produce tendon degeneration.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The non-insertional tendonitis of the tendoachilles is most commonly seen in the runners and the jumpers.

questions.text: High crural index is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jumping athletes

 

Option A)

 

CRURAL INDEX

 

  • Crural index is the ratio of the length of the lower leg to that of the thigh i.e.,

Crural Index = Leg Length/Thigh Length

  • This index is high in the long-jumpers.
  • It is advantageous for the long-jumpers because it enables them to apply a force against the ground for a longer time.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • High crural index is seen in jumping athletes, mainly the long-jumpers.

questions.text: Sudden dorsiflexion of foot may lead to which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tendo-Achilles avulsion injury

 

Option B)

 

TENDON RUPTURE

 

  • The most common mechanism of injury of tendoachilles includes sudden forced plantar flexion of foot, unexpected dorsiflexion of foot and violent dorsiflexion of plantar flexed foot.
  • Other mechanism includes direct trauma and less commonly, attrition of the tendon as a result of long-standing Non-insertional tendonitis with or without peri-tendinitis that body is unable to repair.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior talofibular ligament injury. This ligament of the ankle is injured from an inversion force on the plantarflexed foot.

 

Option C. Rupture of deltoid ligament. Deltoid ligament of the ankle is ruptured due to eversion &/or pronation injury, or can be associated with lateral ankle fractures.

 

Option D. Tarsal tunnel syndrome. This can be caused from extrinsic factors like poor fitted footwear, valgus/varus hindfoot, lower extremity edema, systemic inflammatory arthropathy or diabetes; and intrinsic factors like tendinopathy, tenosynovitis, or osteophytes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sudden dorsiflexion of the foot may lead to avulsion injury of the tendo-achilles.

questions.text: All are the common sites of tendon rupture except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor Hallucis longus tendon

 

Option D)

 

TENDON RUPTURE

 

  • Tendon ruptures are more common in middle-aged and elderly patients.
  • Intrinsic weakness of the tendon as a result of repetitive microtrauma and incomplete healing in watershed areas of vascularity predispose to tendon rupture in some more commonly ruptured tendons, including the supraspinatus, biceps, and Achilles tendons.
  • Most frequent cause of partial or complete rupture of a muscle or tendon is eccentric overload of the muscle tendon unit.
  • One factor contributing to muscle overload is fatigue in runners and jumpers.
  • Strains most commonly occur in muscles that cross two joints, muscles that have higher percentage of type II fast twitch muscle fibers, and weaker muscle of an agonist-antagonist muscle group, e.g. hamstring, gastrocnemius and rectus femoris.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Extensor hallucis longus tendon rupture is relatively rare. The primary cause of its rupture can be a laceration with a sharp object.
  • Achilles tendon, supraspinatus tendon, and long head of biceps brachii are more commonly ruptured tendons.

questions.text: Ruptured tendon is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Athletes

 

Option C)

 

TENDON RUPTURE

 

  • Achilles tendon rupture commonly occurs to otherwise healthy men between the ages of 30 and 50 years who have no previous injury or problem reported in affected leg; typically, “weekend warriors” who are active in sports activity intermittently.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tendon disorders are common.
  • Tears can occur in healthy tendons that are acutely overloaded (e.g., during a high speed or high impact event) or lacerated (e.g., a knife injury).
  • Tendinitis or tendinosis can occur in tendons exposed to overuse conditions (e.g., swimmer's) or intrinsic tissue degeneration (e.g., age-related degeneration).
  • Tendon ruptures are commonly seen in athletes or the weekend warriors (males or 30-50 years of age involved in sports activity intermittently).

choices.text: Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint, ulnar collateral ligament rupture
Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint, radial collateral ligament rupture
Thumb interphalangeal joint, ulnar collateral ligament rupture
Thumb interphalangeal joint, radial collateral ligament rupture

questions.text: Game keepers thumb is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint ulnar collateral ligament rupture

 

Option A)

 

GAMEKEEPER’S THUMB

 

  • Injury to the thumb metacarpophalangeal joint and ulnar collateral ligament, is commonly referred to as gamekeeper thumb or skier’s thumb.
  • It is most common injury of 1st MCP joint.
  • Snow skiing accidents and falls on an outstretched hand with forceful radial and palmar abduction of the thumb are the usual causes.
  • Patients commonly report pain, swelling and ecchymosis around the metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Tenderness is greatest over the ulnar aspect of the joint, but is not localized.
  • Differentiating between an incomplete and complete rupture of the ulnar collateral ligament is necessary because incomplete ruptures are treated non-operatively, and complete ruptures require surgery.
  • Stener described the anatomical pathology. He found the adductor aponeurosis interposed between the ruptured ulnar collateral ligament and its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx (Stener’s lesion).
  • On clinical examination, a prominent lump can be palpated, which represents the ulnar collateral ligament being displaced by the adductor aponeurosis.
  • Pathological rotation of the thumb also may be evident.
  • If left uncorrected, this lesion prevents proper healing and leads to chronic instability and subsequent arthrosis.
  • MRI can distinguish complete from incomplete tears.

 

 

  • Incomplete ruptures of the ulnar collateral ligament of the thumb are common and require only proper protection for restoration of function, although pain and swelling may persist for several months.
  • A thumb spica cast or functional brace is recommended for 4-6 weeks.
  • Acute complete rupture of the ulnar collateral ligament and Stener lesion should be treated with surgical repair of the ligament.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint, radial collateral ligament rupture. Injuries to the radial collateral ligament (RCL) of the thumb are relatively uncommon when compared to the ulnar side. Injury to the radial collateral ligament most commonly results from a sudden thumb metacarpophalangeal adduction or from axial loading of the thumb.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Gamekeeper’s thumb is the rupture of the ulnar collateral ligament on the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb due to forceful radial and palmar abduction of the thumb.

questions.text: A Cricketer while catching a Ball, gets hit on thumb. Which damage should be looked for specifically?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar collateral ligament

 

Option A)

 

GAMEKEEPER’S THUMB

 

  • While catching the ball, the ulnar collateral ligament of the thumb on the MCP joint has been injured in this case.
  • Gamekeeper’s or Skier’s thumb is caused when the ulnar collateral ligament of the thumb gets injured.
  • Snow skiing accidents and falls on an outstretched hand with forceful radial and palmar abduction of the thumb are the usual causes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Volar plate. Volar plate is injured when the thumb is hyperextended or hyperabducted. This is called a jammed or sprained finger. Along with the volar plate, the collateral ligament tear or a bone avulsion can also occur.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While catching a ball, the ulnar collateral ligament of the thumb is most likely to be injured in a cricketer.

questions.text:
Regarding No Man’s land in hand surgery, all of the following statements are false except: 

 

  1. Results of flexor tendon repair & satisfactory in this area
  2. Comprises zone II
  3. Extends from distal palmar crease and flexor crease of PIP
  4. Extends from distal palmar crease and insertion of flexor superficialis
  5. It is for extensor tendons
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

Option A)

 

ZONES AND PULLEYS OF HAND

 

 

ZONE II

 

  • Situated between the opening of the flexor sheath (the distal palmar crease) and insertion of flexor superficialis (flexor crease of proximal interphalangeal joint).
  • It is known as ‘no man’s land’ or dangerous area of hand.
  • The results of flexor tendon repair is worst in this area because both superficial and deep tendons run together in a tight sheath and passes through three pulleys.

 

 

Zones of flexor tendon of hand

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The no man’s land is a part of the zone II of the flexor tendons of the hand.
  • It extends from the distal palmar crease and flexor crease of the PIP joint.
  • Originating from the distal palmar crease, it inserts into the flexor superficialis.
  • The results of flexor tendon repair are worst in this area because both the superficial and deep tendons run through a tight sheath and 3 pulleys through this zone.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the weak leg straight. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoover’s Sign

 

Option C)

 

HOOVER’S SIGN

 

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of contralateral limb against resistance.
