  • Method: Examiner places one hand under heel of normal limb and contralateral hip flexion is done by patient against resistance.
  • Interpretation:
     
    • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb → heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
    • Functional Weakness: Heel does not pushdown, i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Waddell’s test. It is consists of tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if positive, 0 if negative. Components of test are:

 

 

 

If 3+ points or more are present, investigate for non-organic cause.

 

Option B. O’Donoghue’s test. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.

 

Option D. McMurray test. It is used to check for meniscus tear. The patient lies supine with the knee flexed. The examiner holds the knee and palpates the joint line with the proximal hand. With the distal hand, the examiner holes the sole of the foot. From the flexed position, the examiner extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and applies a varus stress, then return to maximal flexion and extend the knee with external rotation of tibia and valgus stress. Internal rotation + varus stress tests the lateral meniscus, while external rotation + valgus stress tests the medial meniscus. The test is positive if there is pain, snapping, an audible click or locking.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s test.

questions.text: Straight leg raising test is positive in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolapsed intervertebral disc

 

Option C)

 

STRAIGHT LEG RAISING TEST

 

  • Straight leg raising is restricted (normal is up to 90°).
  • The Lasegue sign (pain when the affected limb is elevated) is positive in 98% cases and cross Lasegue sign/crossed sciatic tension (pain radiating to affected leg when contralateral leg is elevated) is positive in 20%.
  • Midline tenderness, paravertebral spasm and femoral stretch test is seen in upper or mid lumbar prolapse.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spinal stenosis. In spinal stenosis, the SLR test is negative.

 

Option B. Spinal abscess. The SLR test can be positive in about 11-13% of cases of spinal abscess.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • SLR test is positive in Prolapsed intervertebral disc.

questions.text: Removal of vertebral disc is done by all these methods except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laminoplasty

 

Option C)

 

SURGICAL TREATMENT FOR INTERVERTEBRAL DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • For operative removal of disc, surgical options are unilateral laminectomy/laminotomy or microscopic disc removal or endoscopic disc removal.

 

Discectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Laminotomy. In laminotomy, a piece of the bone is removed that is pressing on the nerves. The bone piece can be a bony spur impinging on the nerves. This can be used for prolapsed intervertebral disc or spinal stenosis (MC).

 

 

Option B. Laminectomy. This procedure involves the removal of the entire lamina of the vertebra. Removal of lamina is followed by discectomy to remove the herniated disc. This is the most commonly performed procedure for the herniated disc in lumbar and cervical regions.

 

 

Option C. Laminoplasty. Cervical laminoplasty is an effective and useful technique for the surgical treatment of degenerative cervical myelopathy.

 

Option D. Hemilaminectomy. Hemilaminectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to decompress the neural tissues. Decompression involves the removal of structures/tissues compressing/irritating the spinal nerves. The hemilaminectomy differs from laminectomy surgery in the removal of a very small part of the lamina. The surgery is commonly used to relieve symptoms caused by spinal stenosis and PIVD in the lumbar spine.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The removal of vertebral disc in case of PIVD or spinal canal stenosis is done by laminotomy/laminectomy/hemilaminectomy.
  • Laminoplasty procedure is used for the treatment of cervical myelopathy.

choices.text: Severe pain interfering with activity and not relieved by rest and treatment of 8 weeks
Patient of PID with difficulty in ambulation

questions.text: When do you operate for prolapsed disc?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe pain interfering with activity and not relieved by rest and treatment of 8 weeks

 

Option C)

 

INDICATIONS FOR SURGERY FOR PROLAPSED DISC

 

Absolute indications:

 

  1. Bladder and bowel involvement (Cauda Equina Syndrome)
  2. Increasing neurological deficit

 

Relative indications:

 

  1. Failure of conservative treatment – Up to 6 weeks of trial is usually given
  2. Recurrent sciatica: 1st attack – 90% recover; 2nd attack 90% recover – 50% recurrent – consider surgery; 3rd attack – 90% recover but all recurrent propose surgery
  3. Significant neurological deficit with SLR reduction
  4. Disc rupture in stenotic canal
  5. Recurrent neurological deficit

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Presence of severe pain interfering the daily activities and not relieving with rest/conservative treatment for 8 weeks is a relative indication for surgery for PIVD.

questions.text: Test used for prolapsed lumbar intervertebral disc is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lasegue test

 

Option B)

 

TEST FOR PIVD

 

  • Straight leg raising is restricted (normal is up to 90°).
  • The Lasegue sign (pain when the affected limb is elevated) is positive in 98% cases and cross Lasegue sign/crossed sciatic tension (pain radiating to affected leg when contralateral leg is elevated) is positive in 20%.
  • Midline tenderness, paravertebral spasm and femoral stretch test is seen in upper or mid lumbar prolapse.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Active straight leg raising test. The Active Straight Leg Raise is used to assess load transference through the pelvis. It is an important test in diagnosing Pelvic Girdle Pain. The aSLR test is considered positive when it elicits pain in the lumbo-pelvic region.

 

Option C. Thomas test. The Thomas Test measures hip flexor length and distinguishes tightness between one joint and two joint muscles.

 

 

Option D. Apley’s grinding test. The Apley grind test or Apley compression test is a maneuver performed to evaluate meniscus injury.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To test prolapsed lumbar intervertebral disc, Lasegue test or straight leg raise test is used.

questions.text: Lumbar canal stenosis presents as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Claudication

 

Option A)

 

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

 

  • Also called Spinal Stenosis
  • Affects Geriatric population
  • There is a decrease in diameter of spinal canal.
  • Spinal Canal diameter < 10 mm is diagnostic.
  • It can be Congenital (e.g. Achondroplasia) or Acquired (Degenerative most common).
  • Causes:
    • Most commonly due to age-related degeneration of spine like osteophytes, herniated discs.
    • Other causes include tumor, growths, congenital or developmental abnormalities.
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain in the buttocks, thighs or calves (Neurogenic Claudication).
    • Characteristically, the pain worsens with standing or walking and may improve on bending forward or sitting. This is called neurogenic claudication.
    • Treatment: Conservative trial is given. If it fails, laminectomy or laminoplasty can be done.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Scoliotic deformity. This is not seen associated with lumbar canal stenosis.

 

Option C. Kyphotic deformity. This is also not associated with lumbar canal stenosis.

 

Option D. Radiculopathy. This may or may not be present in some cases with lumbar canal stenosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lumbar canal stenosis presents as Neurogenic Claudication i.e., worsening of symptoms on standing/walking and relieving on sitting/forward bending.

questions.text: The most common factor causing Lumbar disc prolapse is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less hydrated disc

 

Option A)

 

DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • The lumbar disc is dehydrated, that is why it is more prone to disc prolapse or herniation.
  • With aging, the disc fibrochondrocytes undergo senescence and a reduction in proteoglycans production.
  • This reduction in proteoglycans leads to dehydration and disc collapse, increasing the strain on the annulus fibrosus, resulting in tears and fissures, and consequentially facilitating the nucleus pulposus herniation.
  • Therefore, when repetitive mechanical stressors are applied on the disc, it results in a gradual onset of symptoms that tend to be chronic. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior nucleus pulposus. Nucleus pulposus herniation results from a failure in the annulus fibrosis integrity, making the content of the nucleus to protrude into the neural canal, the intervertebral foramen (foraminal) or lateral to the foramen (extraforaminal). Nucleus pulposus protrusion is the less severe scenario of disc herniation, due to partial rupture of the annulus fibrosis, when the annulus structure becomes completely disrupted, the nucleus content may extrude outside the disc space and in some cases a fragment of nucleus pulposus may migrate (sequestration).

 

Option C. Weak ligamentum flavum. On morphology, there has been no evidence that ligamentum flavum contributes to the development of prolapse intervertebral disc disease.

 

Option D. More degenerative forces. The loss of proteoglycan in degenerated discs has a major effect on the disc's load-bearing behaviour. With loss of proteoglycan, the osmotic pressure of the disc falls and the disc is less able to maintain hydration under load. When loaded, they lose height and fluid more rapidly, and the discs tend to bulge. Due to loss of proteoglycan and matrix disorganization, degenerated discs no longer behave hydrostatically under load. Loading thus leads to inappropriate stress along the end-plate or in the annulus. Such changes in disc behaviour may affect function of other spinal structures and predispose them to injury. For instance, due to rapid loss of disc height under load in degenerated discs, apophyseal joints adjacent to the discs may be subject to abnormal loads and eventually develop osteoarthritic changes. Loss of disc height can also reduce the tensional forces on the ligamentum flavum and hence, may cause remodeling and thickening. With consequent loss of elasticity, the ligament tends to bulge into the spinal canal, leading to spinal stenosis, which is seen most commonly in elderly patients.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the lumbar spine, the most common factor that leads to disc prolapse is the inadequate or less hydration of the disc due to ageing.

questions.text: Most common site for lumbar disc prolapse is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L4-L5

 

Option A)

 

DISC PROLAPSE

 

  • The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine.
  • In more than 95% of cases, lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases).
  • The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6).
  • Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence, more prone.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common site for lumbar disc prolapse are the L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels with L4-L5 > L5-S1.
  • Herniation above this level is more common in people aged > 55 years.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presented with acute onset of low backache radiating to the right lower limb. Examination revealed SLRT < 40 degrees on the right side, weakness of extensor hallucis longus on the right side, sensory loss in the first web space of the right foot and brisk knee jerk. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prolapsed intervertebral disc L4-L5

 

Option A)

 

LUMBAR DISC HERNIATION

 

  • It may occur at any age but is most commonly seen at age group 20-40 years, uncommon in very young and very old.
  • Typically, patient has Sciatica (pain in back radiating to lower limb), commonly preceded by back pain.
  • Both backache and sciatica are made worse by coughing, straining, sneezing or Valsalva manoeuvre and prolonged sitting.
  • Standing and supine position reduces pain.
  • The patient usually stands with slight tilt (list) to one side (sciatic scoliosis).
  • If the disc protrudes medial to the nerve root, the tilt is towards the painful side (to relieve pressure on the root).
  • With the far lateral prolapse, the tilt is away from painful side.
  • Straight leg raising is restricted (normal is up to 90°).
  • The Lasegue sign (pain when the affected limb is elevated) is positive in 98% cases and cross Lasegue sign/crossed sciatic tension (pain radiating to affected leg when contralateral leg is elevated) is positive in 20%.
  • Midline tenderness, paravertebral spasm and femoral stretch test is seen in upper or mid lumbar prolapse.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis L5-S1. Spondylolysis pain feels like a dull ache pain across the low back area. There is soreness and stiffness in the buttocks and back of the thigh. Bending backward or performing twisting movements increases spondylolysis pain in the low back.

 

Option C. Lumbar canal stenosis. Classically, LSS presents with axial low back pain, radiculopathy, or neurological claudication aggravated by ambulation and lumbar extension. Neurogenic claudication is an important feature of LSS. Symptoms are typically bilateral but usually asymmetric. Numbness and tingling typically involve the entire leg. Patients may also report walking upstairs being easier than downstairs. The "shopping cart sign” has also been described, wherein forward flexion relieves back pain. The "simian stance," characterized by walking with the trunk and knees slightly flexed, may be observed.

 

Option D. Spondylolisthesis L4-L5. Spondylolisthesis doesn’t usually have any symptoms. It is commonly seen on X-rays and CT scans as an ‘incidental’ finding. Back pain is the most common symptom that is typically worse with activities such as bending and lifting, and often eases when lying down. As the spine attempts to stabilise the unstable segment, the facet joints enlarge and place pressure on the nerve root causing lumbar spinal stenosis and lateral recess stenosis. As there is forward slippage of one bone on the other, there is also narrowing of the intervertebral foramen (foraminal stenosis). Severe nerve compression can therefore occur with pain, numbness and weakness in the legs. Sometimes loss of control of the bladder and/or bowels can occur due to pressure on the nerves going to these structures.

 

Educational objective:

 

The prolapsed intervertebral disc at L5-S1 may present with symptoms of low back pain radiating to the limb. The SLR test is positive on the affected side, with weakening of the EHL muscle strength, sensory loss on the first web space of the affected side foot and brisk knee jerk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not recommended in the treatment of Chronic Low Back Pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bed rest for 3 months

 

Option B)

 

TREATMENT OF DISC PROLAPSE

 

  1. Rest and Anti-inflammatory Medications: Continuous bed rest for 2 weeks will reduce the herniation in over 90% of cases.
  2. If improvement is not complete, epidural injection of corticosteroid and local anesthetic may help.
  3. Back strengthening should be started only after pain has subsided.
  4. Operative removal of disc options are unilateral laminectomy/laminotomy or microscopic disc removal or endoscopic  disc removal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. NSAIDs. They are usually the first choice of treatment in a low back pain, acute/chronic.

 

Option C. Exercises. After some relief of pain with medications and rest, gentle spine strengthening exercises are recommended under supervision.

 

Option D. Epidural steroid injection. They can be given if there is no improvement in pain with medications, rest and physiotherapy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a chronic low back pain, bed rest is recommended only for about 2 weeks.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with frozen shoulder except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

 

Option C)

 

ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS WITH FROZEIN SHOULDER

 

  • Diabetes mellitus: 10-35% of diabetics develop frozen shoulder
  • Dupuytren’s disease
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Cardiac disease
  • Lung disease
  • Hemiplegia
  • Recovery from neurosurgery

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Frozen shoulder is not associated with psoriasis.

choices.text: Abduction and internal rotation
Adduction and external rotation
All range of movements

questions.text: Which of the following movements are restricted in frozen shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) All range of movements

 

Option C)

 

CLINICAL PRESENTATION OF FROZEN SHOULDER

 

  • The cardinal feature is stubborn lack of active and passive movement in all directions, i.e. global restriction of movements in all planes.
  • Often the first motion to be affected is external rotation followed by abduction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Frozen shoulder involves restriction of all passive and active movements of the shoulder.
  • It first begins with the restriction of external rotation, followed by abduction and extension of the shoulder.
  • The stages begin with restriction of extremes of all movements.

questions.text: Gradual, painful limitation of shoulder movements in an elderly suggest that the most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periarthritis

 

Option B)

 

STAGES OF PERIARTHRITIS SHOULDER

 

A. Painful Inflammatory Freezing Phase: Gradual onset of shoulder pain at rest with sharp pain at extremes of motion, and pain at night with sleep interruption which may last for 2–9 months.

 

B. Phase of Progressive Stiffness: Lasts for 3–12 months. Pain decreases and stiffness increases. Attempt to exceed range of stiffness is accompanied by pain.

 

C. Resolution/Thawing Phase: Lasts for 1–3 years (can be as short as 1 month). Shoulder slowly and progressively becomes more supple.

 

CLINICAL PRESENTATION

 

  • The cardinal feature is stubborn lack of active and passive movement in all directions, i.e. global restriction of movements in all planes.

 

Often the first motion to be affected is external rotation followed by abduction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis. Pain in the shoulder joint is the major sign of arthritis. It can be present in the front, side or back of the shoulder. Some people may have pain even at rest or during any activity. It can be present with or without shoulder stiffness. Often the pain is worse with lifting, carrying heavy objects or after exercising. The pain can often radiate into the arm or, if severe, can radiate down to the elbow and wrist. Stiffness of the joint is another sign of progression of shoulder arthritis. There may be loss of range of motion in the shoulder. Crepitus may be felt which may or may not be painful. Sometimes the shoulder may “lock up.”

 

Option C. Myositis ossificans. Heterotrophic ossification in shoulder is a rare entity. It may occur following a trauma to the shoulder. The patient may present with pain, tenderness, swelling and decreased range of motion within few days of the injury. There may be a palpable soft tissue mass in the shoulder. The pain and the size of the mass decreases with time. There is also restricted shoulder motion.

 

Option D. Fracture-dislocation. The fracture-dislocation presents with pain, swelling and bruising around the affected area. The patient is unable to move the shoulder. There is a crepitus on movement of the shoulder. There is also a presentation of a deformity in the shoulder that does not look right.

 

Educational objective:

 

Gradual, painful limitation of the shoulder movements in an elderly patient suggests that there is a presentation of frozen shoulder or periarthritis of the shoulder.

choices.text: Flexor pollicis longus and brevis
Extensor carpi radialis and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis longus and brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.text: de Quervain’s disease classically affects the:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

Option D)

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.

 

Educational objective:

 

De Quervain’s disease classically affects the extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longu (APL) tendons.

choices.text: Wait and watch

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic/alcoholic patient presented with 15-degree flexion deformity of the little finger. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wait and watch

 

Option A)

 

DUPUYTREN’S CONTRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Wait and watch is the option in this patient because indication of surgery is > 30° MCP joint contracture and > 15° contracture at PIP.
  • Here, most commonly affected joint (MCP) needs to be assumed.
  • Surgery does not cure the disease; it only partially corrects the deformity.
  • Usually done surgery is subtotal fasciectomy.
  • Closure may be done by Z plasty.
  • Severe or recurrent PIP joint disease may need arthrodesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Subtotal fasciectomy. This is the preferred surgical option but surgery usually do not cure the disease; it just improves the function of the hand.

 

Option C. Total fasciectomy. This can be done if a large portion of hand is involved in Dupuytren’s contracture along with contracture of PIP joint volar capsule.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given case scenario with 15° flexion deformity of the finger, wait and watch is the usual treatment option as surgery is indicated when there is >30° of MCP and > 15° of PIP joint contracture.

choices.text: A feature of carpal tunnel syndrome
Injury to fingers while operating a gun
Stenosis tenosynovitis of flexor tendon of affected finger
Any of the above

questions.text: Trigger finger is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stenosis tenosynovitis of flexor tendon of affected finger

 

Option C)

 

TRIGGER FINGER

 

  • Due to stenosing tenosynovitis, the flexor tendon may become trapped at the entrance to its fibrous digital sheath.
  • The usual cause is thickening of fibrous tendon sheath or constriction of mouth of fibrous digital sheath (mainly A1 pulley) at the level of metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A feature of carpal tunnel syndrome. Trigger finger can occur after the carpal tunnel release.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trigger finger is the stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor tendon of the affected finger.

questions.text:
Ganglion is:

 

  1. Cystic tumor of hand
  2. Solid tumor of hand
  3. Treated by enucleation
  4. Unilocular
  5. Filled with mucinous fluid
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

GANGLION

 

  • It is most common soft tissue tumors (swelling) of hand and wrist.
  • It arises from leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath.
  • It is a unilocular cystic structure filled with mucinous fluid but without a synovial or epithelial lining.
  • In most cases, stalk can be identified, communicating between the cyst and adjacent joint or tendon sheath.
  • It usually develops on dorsal surface of scapholunate ligament.
  • Back of wrist is the commonest site.

 

 

  • The three most common location of ganglion are:
    • Dorsal wrist (from scapholunate joint > palmar wrist radioscaphoid or scaphotrapezial joint),
    • Digital flexor sheath and
    • Distal interphalangeal joint.
  • Age: 20-40 years
  • Treatment: 
  1. Usually unnecessary and it may resolve spontaneously.
  2. Aspiration to reassure the patient.
  3. Pressure symptoms (e.g. Nerve) – removal.

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Solid tumor of hand. Solid-appearing ganglia are unusual and may mimic a benign neoplasm or synovitis.

 

  1. Treated by enucleation. The treatment for ganglion cyst is usually leaving it unattended as it may resolve spontaneously, or fluid aspiration can be done to reassure the patient. If the patient experiences pressure symptoms on the nerves, then removal of the cyst is done.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A ganglion cyst is a unilocular cystic tumor of the hand filled with mucinous fluid.

 

The treatment of these cysts are generally leaving the cyst to resolve spontaneously or aspiration of the fluid for patient satisfaction or if the pressure symptoms occur, removal of the cyst is done.

choices.text: Pulsion diverticulum of knee joint

questions.text: Bakers cyst is a type of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulsion diverticulum of knee joint

 

Option A)

 

BAKER’S CYST

 

  • Morrant Baker’s cyst or popliteal cyst is centrally located in popliteal region.
  • It is often bilateral and commonly seen in > 40 Years age group.
  • It is the pressure diverticulum of synovial membrane, so it can be compressed.

 

 

  • It is prominent on extension and reduced on flexion.
  • Usually secondary to osteoarthritis/RA/pigmented Villonodular synovitis/meniscal injury.
  • Swelling is soft and fluctuant.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Baker’s cyst is the pulsion diverticulum of the synovial lining of the knee joint.
  • Most Baker’s cyst has a communication with the synovial cavity of the knee joint, therefore it is not a true cyst.

questions.text: Bursa involved in Clergyman’s knee is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infrapatellar bursa

 

Option B)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prepatellar bursa. It is involved in housemaid’s knee.

 

Option C. Olecranon bursa. It is involved in student’s/miner’s elbow.

 

Option D. Ischial bursa. It is involved in weaver’s bottom.

questions.solution:
Ans. C) Weaver’s bottom

 

Option C)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Clergyman’s knee. It is the bursitis of the infrapatellar bursa.

 

Option B. Housemaid’s knee. It is the bursitis of the prepatellar bursa.

 

Option D. Student’s elbow. It is the bursitis of the olecranon bursa.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ischial bursitis is also known as weaver’s bottom.

choices.text: Great toe MTP joint
Shin of tibia

questions.text: Bunion is commonly seen at:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Great toe MTP joint

 

Option A)

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Medial malleolus. Bursitis of medial malleolus involves pain over the medial malleolus, outside the ankle. It is seen in ice hockey players due to tightly enclosed footwears.

 

Option C. Lateral malleolus. Bursitis of lateral malleolus is called as tailor’s ankle. It is seen in miners sitting with legs crossed in tunnels with low ceilings.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bunion is most commonly seen at the great toe.
  • It forms at the MTP joint, causing the tip of the toe to get pulled towards the smaller toes while forcing the joint to stick out.

questions.text: Housemaid’s knee is bursitis of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prepatellar bursa

 

Option A)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Infrapatellar bursa. Bursitis of infrapatellar bursa is known as clergyman’s knee.

 

Option C. Olecranon. Bursitis of olecranon is known as student’s/miner’s elbow.

Housemaid’s knee is the bursitis of the prepatellar bursa of the knee.

questions.text: Prepatellar bursitis is also known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Housemaid’s knee

 

Option A)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Clergyman’s knee. It is the infrapatellar bursitis of the knee.

  • Prepatellar bursitis is also known as housemaid’s knee.

choices.text: Outward deviation of great toe
Inward deviation of great toe
Outward deviation of fifth toe
Inward deviation of fifth toe

questions.text: Hallux valgus means:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Outward deviation of great toe

 

Option A)

 

HLLUX VALGUS

 

  • It is outward/lateral deviation of great toe.
  • It is the commonest of the foot deformities (and probably of all musculoskeletal deformities).
  • Splaying of forefoot, with varus angulation of 1st metatarsal, predispose lateral angulation of great toe in people who wear shoes.
  • Overriding or under riding of 2nd toe can take place.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inward deviation of great toe. This occurs in hallux varus.

 

Option C. Outward deviation of fifth toe. This occurs in the valgus of the fifth toe.

 

Option D. Inward deviation of fifth toe. This occurs in the varus of the fifth toe.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hallux valgus means outward deviation of the great toe.

choices.text: Difficulty in standing from prolonged sitting
Difficulty in climbing stairs
Pain during intense sporting activities
Pain on posterior aspect of knee

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding patellofemoral stress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on posterior aspect of knee

 

Option D)

 

PATELLOFEMORAL STRESS SYNDROME

 

  • Anterior knee pain
    • Increases on stairs
    • Increases after standing from prolonged sitting (Movie sign)
  • Young females
  • Vastus medialis obliques weakness (Lateral structures stronger)
  • Increased Q angle and genu valgus
  • Treatment: Correct muscle imbalance
  • Complication: may develop patellofemoral arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Difficulty in standing from prolonged standing; Option B. Difficulty in climbing stairs; and Option C. Pain during intense sporting activities are all true regarding patellofemoral stress syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

In patellofemoral stress syndrome, there is pain on the anterior aspect of the knee and not posterior.

questions.text: A 15-year-old Female complains of anterior knee pain which increased on climbing stairs and getting up after prolonged sitting. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chondromalacia patellae

 

Option A)

 

CHONDROMALACIA PATELLAE

 

  • It is characterized by anterior knee pain and degeneration of articular cartilage of patella (basal degeneration) due to decrease in sulfated mucopolysaccharidosis in cartilage.
  • It is seen in adolescent females.
  • The patient has chief complaint of difficulty in climbing stairs.
  • Movie sign is seen which is described as an increased pain on getting up after prolonged sitting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bipartite patella. Bipartite patella is congenital fragmentation of patella and is usually asymptomatic.

 

Option C. Plica syndrome. Plica syndrome presents with meniscal symptoms of locking.

 

Option D. Patellofemoral arthritis. Patellofemoral arthritis will be seen at a later age and will have pain in all movements of knee.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given complaints of the patient of anterior knee pain which increases on climbing stairs and getting up after prolonged sitting are clinically diagnostic of chondromalacia patellae.

questions.text: K.L. splint is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plantar fasciitis

 

Option B)

 

PLANTAR FASCIITIS

 

  • Treatment options for plantar fasciitis include rest physical therapy, cold therapy, heat therapy, orthotics (K.L. splint), anti-inflammatory medications, injection of corticosteroids and surgery in refractory case.

 

 

KL Splint for plantar fasciitis

 

Night splints place the ankle in anatomical position to reduce nocturnal contractures of the gastrocnemius-soleus complex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture tibia. For the conservative management of a mid-shaft tibial fracture, a tibia brace is used.

 

 

Option C. de Quervain’s tenosynovitis. To treat de Quervain’s tenosynovitis, thumb splints are used.

 

 

Option D. Tennis elbow. for tennis elbow, tennis elbow brace is used.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

KL splint is used for plantar fasciitis.

questions.text: Impingement syndrome refers to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Soft tissues entrapment

 

Option B)

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

Impingement syndrome is a painful encroachment of joint motion caused by protruding bony or soft tissue structures.

 

Impingement syndromes can occur at any age.

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Developmental osseous anomalies
  • Overuse activity
  • Trauma

 

Associations:

 

  • Osteoarthritis
  • Tendinosis and tears
  • Myotendinous injury
  • Bursitis
  • Chondral and labral injury

 

The usual presentation of impingement syndrome is a painful reduction in the range of motion of the affected joint.

 

Typical locations are the following joints:

 

  • Shoulder
  • Hip
  • Ankle
  • Wrist
  • Knee

 

Classification:

 

  • Internal impingement: refers to an intraarticular impingement i.e., the affected structures are within the joint, e.g. femoroacetabular impingement, anterior, anteromedial, anterolateral, posterior or posteromedial ankle impingement, subcoracoid impingement
  • External impingement: refers to an extra-articular impingement i.e., the affected structures lie outside the joint, e.g. ischiofemoral impingement, extra-articular lateral hindfoot impingement

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nerve entrapped in closed space. Entrapment neuropathy is a condition in which a nerve is compressed or entrapped between two structures (ligament and bone). Repetitive motion can cause the ligament and bone to press or rub against the nerve. Over time, this damages the myelin sheath. This causes symptoms of numbness, tingling, burning, or weakness in the fingers or extremities. Usually not serious, entrapment neuropathy can be painful and can affect function if not treated.

 

Educational objective:

 

Impingement syndrome refers to the entrapment of the soft tissue between two bony structures.

questions.text:
About Kienbock Osteonecrosis, all are true except: 

 

  1. Tenderness over base of 5th metatarsal is present
  2. Pain is more on wrist flexion than wrist extension
  3. Is the osteochondritis of lunate
  4. Is associated with positive ulnar variance
  5. More common in elderly
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

KIENBOCK DISEASE

 

  • Age: 20-40 years
  • Osteochondritis of lunate
  • Dominant side
  • Finesterer’s sign: Tenderness at base of 3rd metacarpal on making a fist.
  • Negative ulnar variance (ulnar articular surface short of radial surface)
  • Pain on wrist dorsiflexion
  • Treatment:
    • Early stage: correct negative ulnar variance and vascularized pronator quadratus graft.
    • Advanced stage with collapse: wrist arthrodesis or arthroplasty.

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Tenderness over base of 5th metatarsal is present. False. Kienbock’s osteonecrosis presents with tenderness at the base of the 3rd metacarpal when the patient makes a fist.
  2. Pain is more on wrist flexion than wrist extension. False. The patient experiences pain more on dorsiflexion or extension of the wrist.
  3. Is the osteochondritis of lunate. True. Kienbock’s disease is the osteochonditis or osteonecrosis of the lunate bone.
  4. Is associated with positive ulnar variance. False. Kienbock is associated with negative ulnar variance i.e., the ulnar articular surface is shorter than the radial surface.
  5. More common in elderly. False. Kienbock’s is seen commonly in 20-40 years of age group.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Kienbock’s osteonecrosis presents with tenderness at the base of the 3rd metacarpal.
  • The patient experiences pain more on dorsiflexion of the wrist.
  • Kienbock is associated with negative ulnar variance.
  • Kienbock’s is seen commonly in 20-40 years of age group.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle

 

Option D)

 

HAGLUND DEFORMITY

 

  • Haglund deformity is prominent Calcaneal tuberosity and overlying bursitis (retro-calcaneal).

 

  

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

questions.text: Freiberg’s osteochondritis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2nd Metatarsal head

 

Option A)

 

TYPES OF OSTEOCHONDRITIS

 

 

 

Freiberg disease

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Freiberg disease is the osteochondritis of the head of 2nd metatarsal bone.

questions.text:
True about avascular necrosis of femur are: 

 

  1. Affected side hip is kept non-weight bearing
  2. Asymptomatic cases may occur
  3. Radionuclide scan show increased uptake due to new bone formation in the area around the infarct
  4. Trendelenburg sign is negative
  5. MRI is investigation of choice
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Option D)

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS OF FEMUR

 

Avascular necrosis is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.

 

Affects Anterolateral Aspect of Femoral Head.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Age of 20–50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male)
  • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid induced cases
  • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction
  • Femoral head shape is altered
  • Sectoral sign: with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed, it is grossly restricted because a sector of femoral head is involved in AVN
  • X-rays shows area of necrosis and Crescent sign in subchondral area

 

 

  • MRI is investigation of choice - double line sign is seen

 

 

  • Trendelenburg test is positive in AVN

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Affected side hip is kept in non-weight bearing. True statement.
  2. Asymptomatic cases may occur. True statement.  
  3. Radionuclide scan shows increased uptake due to new bone formation in the area around the infarct. True statement.
  4. Trendelenburg sign is negative. False. Trendelenburg sign is positive in this condition.
  5. MRI is the investigation of choice. True statement.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the AVN of femoral head, the affected side hip is kept non-weight bearing;
  • It may present with asymptomatic cases.
  • Radionuclide scan shows increased uptake due to new bone formation in the area around the infarct.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

questions.text:
Potential causes of AVN include: 

 

  1. Prolonged intake of steroids
  2. Caisson’s disease
  3. Sickle cell anemia
  4. Posterior dislocation hip
  5. Intracapsular fracture femur neck
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Option D)

 

CAUSES OF AVN OF FEMORAL HEAD

 

  • Idiopathic (most common) – Called as Chandelier’s Disease
  • Trauma: Neck femur fracture, Posterior dislocation of hip (>12-hour duration)
  • Substance: Alcohol, steroid use
  • Infection: Septic arthritis, osteomyelitis
  • Storage disorders: Gaucher’s disease
  • Caisson disease: Dysbaric osteonecrosis (Nitrogen accumulates)
  • Hemoglobinopathy and Coagulation disorder: Sickle cell disease, Familial thrombophilia A. Hypofibrinolysis, Hypolipoproteinemia.
  • Congenital disorders: Perthes disease, Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
  • Hematological malignancies: Leukemia, lymphoma, polycythemia
  • Hyperlipidemia: Nephrotic syndrome
  • Other: SLE, ionizing radiation, Pregnancy, pancreatitis, Amyloid, Renal failure and dialysis, Hyperparathyroidism

 

Educational objective:

 

The potential causes of AVN of femoral head are prolonged intake of steroids, Caisson’s disease, sickle cell anemia, posterior hip dislocation, and intracapsular femoral neck fracture.

questions.text: Femur head avascular necrosis is due to damage to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial circumflex arteries

 

Option A)

 

BLOOD SUPPLY TO FEMORAL HEAD

 

  • Crock described the blood supply to the proximal end of the femur, dividing it into three major groups:
    1. An extracapsular arterial ring located at the base of the femoral neck
    2. Ascending cervical branches of the arterial ring on the surface of the femoral neck
    3. Arteries of the ligamentum teres
  • The extracapsular arterial ring is formed posteriorly by a large branch of the medial femoral circumflex artery and anteriorly by a branch from the lateral femoral circumflex artery.
  • The ascending cervical branches or retinacular vessels ascend on the surface of the femoral neck in anterior, posterior, medial, and lateral groups; the lateral vessels are the most important.
  • Their proximity to the surface of the femoral neck makes them vulnerable to injury in femoral neck fractures.
  • As the articular margin of the femoral head is approached by the ascending cervical vessels, a second, less distinct ring of vessels is formed, referred to by Chung as the subsynovial intra-articular arterial ring.
  • It is from ring of vessels that vessels penetrate the head and are referred to as the epiphyseal arteries, the most important being the lateral epiphyseal arterial group supplying the lateral weight bearing portion of the femoral head.
  • These epiphyseal vessels are joined by inferior metaphyseal vessels and vessels from the ligamentum teres.

 

 

Blood supply to femur head (Posterior aspect)

 

Intraosseous Blood Supply:

 

  • Cartilaginous growth plate starts appearing at 4 Years of age, so metaphyseal arteries do not enter after 4 years of age.
  • When growth plate disappears in adolescence, metaphyseal arteries enter epiphysis again.
  • Foveal artery appears at 8 years of age.
  • So, most precarious blood supply is at age 4-8 years (Truetas hypothesis).
  • Hence, this is the age in which AVN of femoral epiphysis is seen in children called as Perthes disease.
  • In fracture neck femur, the more proximal the lesion, more are the chances of avascular necrosis.
  • So, subcapital fracture neck femur has maximum chances of AVN (worst prognosis).
  • Subcapital > transcervical > basicervical fracture is order of risk of development of Avascular necrosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The proximity of the medial circumflex artery to the femoral neck surface makes it more prone to damage due to fracture of the femoral neck, that leads to AVN of the hip.

questions.text: AVN can occur at all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Femur neck

 

Option A)

 

AVN OF BONE

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • These types of questions are to see your reflex.
  • Please remember that femur neck fracture causes AVN at head of femur and not at the neck of femur, so answer is neck femur, as all other sites have avascular necrosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV positive male who is on antiretroviral therapy (protease inhibitors) has pain in the right hip joint for 2 months. He has difficulty in abduction and internal rotation. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Avascular necrosis

 

Option C)

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS IN HIV

 

  • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation is a characteristic clinical feature of altered shape of femoral head.
  • It is seen in AVN and can be seen in Perthes or Slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
  • Use of Protease inhibitor in HIV patients is associated with an increased risk of avascular necrosis of femoral head (AVN) or Osteonecrosis.
  • In this question, if it is asked that patient has Flexion, Abduction and External rotation deformity then, Tuberculosis will be a better answer because this is seen in Stage 1 of Tuberculosis of hip and is usually not seen in AVN.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Since, this question has mentioned about difficulty in abduction and internal rotation, so the correct answer has to be AVN of the hip.
  • If it is given restriction of abduction and internal rotation, mark the answer as avascular necrosis and if it is mentioned flexion, abduction and external rotation deformity, then answer is tuberculosis.
